loans.name: Rashid

texts.en:
Rashid is an existing Kiva client. Now he applies for the loan of 2,000 AZN to buy fruit and vegetables to improve his business.

When he applied for his first loan, he sold only cabbages and then with this loan he improved his business and started selling fruits and vegetables.

"I am very thankful to Kiva for this business that you see in the photo!"

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Zahidah

texts.en:
Zahida is a hardworking woman who spent her life as a janitor in a public school. She recently reached retirement and has a monthly pension of around 400 USD. Zahida has three adult children: one of them is working as a daily paid worker in Israel while the other two are working in Tulkarem city.

Zahida’s husband is suffering from prostate cancer and he needs treatment in Jordan. The health insurance (government insurance) will cover part of the cost while the other part will be covered from this FATEN loan of 2,000 USD that Zahida has requested.

Zahida appears in the photo at the FATEN office.

loans.use: To pay for her husband's treatment

location.town: Ertah Village, Tulkarem City, West Bank

loans.name: Tas-Try Group

texts.en:
These are members of the Tas-Try group. They are small-scale entrepreneurs in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. They have applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to strengthen their businesses. In this way, they can better provide for their children in terms of feeding, clothing, and educating them.

The leader of the group is Fatmata K., on the left. Fatmata was born in Masongbo village, about three miles from Makeni city. Fatmata is approximately forty-two years of age. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a driver and her children are attending secondary schools.

Fatmata sells rice and palm-oil, i.e., the country’s most popular cooking oil. She has had over fifteen years of experience in this business. With her share of the loan, Fatmata will buy more bags of rice and more gallons of palm-oil to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy gallons of palm-oil and bags of rice

loans.name: Poeu

texts.en: Poeu Y., 56, is a cake-seller living in Kampong Chhnang province. She is a widow and lives with two daughters, one of whom is married and the other single. To help feed the family better, one of her daughters sells beef soup in front of her home. Poeu Y.’s daughter started selling soup months ago, but she doesn’t have enough equipment to do her best at her trade. That is why Poeu Y. has requested a loan to allow her daughter to buy more equipment. She hopes to use some of the loan to buy two piglets to raise.

loans.use: To buy more equipment

loans.name: Tawana's Group

texts.en:
Towana C. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God First. She is 43 years old and a widow with seven children between the ages of 6 and 27. She also cares for two brothers. She is an illiterate due to lack of financial support. Towana and her family live in the Melekie community close to Gbarnga city, the capital of Bong county, Liberia.

Her business is the sale of general goods. She buys goods wholesale and sells retail to residents of her community. Towana has been running this business for ten years, and hopes to upgrade her business to a shop.

The transportation of goods to her business site is a difficulty for Towana, because the road conditions are very bad. Because of that, drivers charge huge amounts to take goods from one location to another.

Towana has always had good relationships with her customers in order to encourage them to continue to patronize her business.

She needs this loan to purchase more new goods to increase sales. She dreams of giving her children a better education.

loans.use: to purchase more new goods to improve sales.

loans.name: Mojisola

texts.en:
Mojisola sells smoked fish at the market in Lagos state, Nigeria. The demands for her smoked fish are high and she hopes to satisfy her customers. Smoked fish is used in the preparation of local soups in Nigeria. Mojisola has been in this business since 2004.

She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria. She lives in Alaba, Lagos state. She is 35 years old and has four children.

Mojisola hopes for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more smoked fish to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more smoked fish to sell

loans.name: Do-Better-Tin Group

texts.en:
These are small-scale businesswomen in the northern city of Makeni. They have come to SMT for the very first time to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to expand their businesses. With a loan of SLL 500,000, they will be able to add more stocks to their businesses, make more sales, and more profit. Consequently, they will be able to improve their standard of living by sending their children to school, feeding them well, and clothing them.

Sonita K. on the left is the leader of this group. She was born in Makeni, twenty-four years ago. She is single with two children. Sonita has been selling rice, palm-oil (the post popular cooking oil), and groundnuts/peanuts for three years now. Sonita will use this loan to expand her business by buying more bags of rice and groundnuts, and more gallons of palm-oil.

loans.use: Expand her business by adding more rice, palm-oil and ground-nuts

loans.name: Chikaodile

texts.en:
Chikaodile produces and sells cellophane at retail prices to her customers. She also has a machine that she uses to produce popcorn to sell. She lives in Lagos state, Nigeria. Chikaodile is 44 years old and has seven children. Her children are excelling in their school work.

She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria. She hopes for a loan of 70,000 NGN to purchase more materials to produce more cellophane to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more materials to produce more cellophane to sell

loans.name: Yopi

texts.en:
Yopi E. is currently in the business of selling tea and bread in a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase sodas, beer and water to sell.  Yopi is 30 years old and married to a soldier. She has four children and they all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to purchase sodas,beer and water to sell.

loans.name: Zeveleekeze Group

texts.en:
Catherine M. is the leader of a group of four borrowers called "Zeveleekeze." She is 34 years old and and a single mother of a 7-year-old child in the 2nd grade at school. Catherine is illiterate due to lack of financial support. Catherine and her child live in Gbarnga, the capital of Bong County, Liberia. 

Catherine sells used clothing in the Gbarnga Central Market. She buys the used clothes from wholesalers and sells them retail to residents of her community. She sells high quality used clothing to encourage the her customers to patronize her business. Catherine has been running this business for 4 years, and hopes to improve the business to meet international standard in the near future. 

The high cost of transporting her goods to her business site is a difficulty for Catherine’s business. Drivers charge huge amounts to take goods from one destination to another.

Catherine needs this loan to purchase more goods to improve her business. Catherine dreams of building her family up in a very good manner.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to sell

loans.name: Lovelyn

texts.en: Lovelyn sells drinks and cooked food in her shop. Lovelyn has been in this business for 4 years. She is a hard-working woman who is determined to excel in her business. She is 34 years old and has 4 children. Lovelyn lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is a client of the Lift above Poverty Organization (LAPO). LAPO  is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and throughout Africa. She is hoping for a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more drinks and food to cook and sell. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and food to cook and sell

loans.name: Peter Njoroge

texts.en:
Peter M. is separated from his wife. He lives in Nairobi. Peter was introduced to KADET by existing clients and has no previous credit or loan history from any other microfinance institutions. 

Peter has been running a laundry service for six years. He also sells DVD's and operates an M-Pesa (a mobile-phone based money-transfer service that allows users to deposit, withdraw, and transfer money, and pay bills, at very affordable rates without visiting a bank). Peter operates his businesses in a residential area of Nairobi. Peter intends to use the loan to add credit to his M-Pesa business. He anticipates extra profits that he will invest in a new laundry machine. 

Peter hopes to own several M-Pesa branches and outlets. He believes he is a hard worker he knows he will accomplish this task.

loans.use: To add credit to his M-Pesa business.

loans.name: Vagif

texts.en:
Vagif was born in 1985. He lives in Fuzuli region. This young man is single. He has been in the auto-repair business for 3 years. 
He needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy the spare parts to improve his auto-repair business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Lillian

texts.en:
Lillian lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 25 years old and married, and has 3 children, all of whom excel in school.

Lillian sells hair extensions and hair cream to her customers. She has been in this business for 3 years. This is the busy season for her business and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. 

Lillian is a client of Lift above Poverty Organization (LAPO), a Kiva field partner that is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and throughout Africa. She is hoping for a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more hair extensions and cream to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and cream to sell

loans.name: Wani

texts.en:
E. Wani sells soft drinks, such as soda, water, and juice. She is requesting a loan to stock beer and wines to sell. Wani is 34 years old and is married to a plumber. She has 3 children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock beer and wines to sell.

loans.name: Nediah Group

texts.en:
Luna Q. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called "Nediah." She is a single mother with 7 children, ages 10-35 years old. Her children's educational levels range from Kindergarten to 4th grade. Luna dropped out of school in 3rd grade due to a lack of financial support. Luna and her children live in the Duta community of Gbarnga, the capital of Bong County, Liberia.

Luna sells fish and oil. She buys fish from fishermen and the oil from rural Liberia and she sells it retail to residents of her community in Gbarnga. Luna has been running this business for 4 years, and hope to improve business so she can open a shop. 

The high cost of transporting goods to her business site and the rainy season are the difficulties Luna faces in her business. She needs this loan to purchase more goods to sell. Luna dreams of giving her children a better education.

loans.use: To purchase more fish and oil to sell

loans.name: Aune

texts.en:
Aune E. sells tomatoes, groundnut paste, and rice. She is requesting a loan to buy more groundnuts to make paste. Aune is 38 years old and is married to a peasant. She has 8 children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy groundnuts to make groundnut paste

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en:
Dorothy is 31 years old and married. She has three children between the ages of nine and fourteen. Dorothy sells shoes and textiles and also provides tailoring services. She describes herself as hard-working and committed.

Dorothy successfully repaid a previous loan of Kes. 20,000 from Faulu. She is requesting this loan of Kes. 40,000 to purchase more stock. She says that through Faulu's training, she has learned to manage her business more professionally. In the future, she hopes to open a boutique and also sell her goods wholesale.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing and shoes to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells sarongs of various colors and shapes. She hawks (sells door-to-door) her sarongs within her community. She has been in this business for 5 years. She Josephine is 47 years old and married with 5 children. 

Josephine is a client of Lift above Poverty Organization (LAPO). LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and throughout Africa. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Munene

texts.en:
Munene is 36 years old. He is married to Mercy and they have one daughter. He has been farming maize and beans for 10 years. He also sells rice as another source of income. Munene does not have a permanent structure for his rice business, so he fulfills customer orders that he gets from different towns.

Munene learned about Kadet through a marketing outreach and decided to become a client. He has applied for a loan of Kenya shillings 30,000. In his budget, he plans to use about Kenya shillings 5,000 to buy fertilizer for the farm and Kenya 25,000 to buy rice to sell. He knows that the prices for the rice are normally low, especially during the months of December and January, because it is harvest time, so he wants to maximize his profit before January. With the extra profits from his business, he intends to purchase a water pump to improve his farm, which has been affected by drought. 

He dreams of improving his family's living standards, educating his children, and building a better house for his family. He describes himself as a hard-working man.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and rice

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a 31-year-old single man. He has owned a wheel shop in his town since 2005. He supports his parents with his business. Ahmad is asking for a loan of $1,000 to buy a particular wheel machine to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy a wheel machine

loans.name: Serifat

texts.en:
Serifat sells foods, like yams, garri (cassava flakes) and rice, in her shop in Lagos State, Nigeria. She has been in this business for 6 years. She is happily married with 5 children and she is 45 years old.

Serifat is a client of the Lift above Poverty Organization (LAPO). LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and throughout Africa. She is hoping for a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more food to sell. She says "thank you."

loans.use: To purchase more food to sell

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji A. bakes and sells local Sudanese bread. She is requesting a loan to stock more materials for baking so she can bake more bread to sell. Keji is 39 years old and is married to a journalist. She has 3 children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a bigger bakery.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more baking materials

loans.name: Dekagar Group

texts.en:
Stephen B. J. is the leader of a 5-member loan group called "Dekagar." He is married and has 3 children, ages 4 - 13 years old. His children's educational levels range from Kindergarten to 9th grade. Stephen is a high school graduate, but could not continue to university due to lack of financial support. Stephen and his family live and work in the Duta community of Gbarnga, the capital of Bong County, Liberia. 

Stephen sells medical drugs. He buys drugs wholesale and sells retail to residents of his community. Stephen has been running this business for 3 years, and hopes to improve business so that he can open a pharmacy. Stephen's most significant challenge is the irregular payments he receives from customers who owe him money.

Stephen needs this loan to purchase more new goods to improve his business. He dreams of giving his children a better education.

loans.use: To purchase more new goods to improve his business

loans.name: Value Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the group called 'Value Group' who have come to SMT for the first time to seek a loan of SLL 2,000,000 (or SLL 500,000 each). They are small-scale businesswomen who want a loan in order to further improve their businesses by adding more goods to their current stock. In this way, their living standard will improve, they can better provide for their children in terms of feeding, clothing them, and paying their school fees. 


Mamusu on the left is the leader of this group. Mamusu is approximately forty-five years of age, a widow with three children. Mamusu has been selling 'gara' clothes (locally dyed clothes) for many countless years. She will use this loan to further expand her business by buying lengths of white cotton, inks, caustic soda, powder and paying experts to make designs on the white cotton.

loans.use: Buy working materials like white cotton, inks, caustic soda, powder and pay designers to decorate the cloth

loans.name: Afees

texts.en:
Afees is 33 years old. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She has 4 children and she is happily married. 

Afees sells frozen foods to her customers at retail prices . This is the busy season for her business and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She has been in this business for 8 years. 

Afess is a client of the Lift above Poverty Organization (LAPO). LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and throughout Africa. She is hoping for a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more frozen foods to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Khadije

texts.en: Khadije is a 60 year old married woman with 2 children. She has been working as a tailor since 1980. After this long period working in this field, she is known in the neighboring villages for her extensive experience. Today, Khadije is requesting a loan of $1,000 to buy textiles in order to expand her business and allow her to make a variety of products.

loans.use: To buy textiles

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein has owned a photography shop since 2007. He has been working in photography for the past 8 years. He's 36 years old. He really loves his job because he think that it's creative and artistic. Today, Hussein is requesting a loan of $1,200 to buy a new photography machine.

loans.use: To buy a new photography machine

loans.name: Mohamad Ali

texts.en: Mohamad Ali is a 46-year-old married man and the father of 3 children. He has been painting homes and furniture since 1987. His services are in great demand, so he wants to borrow $1,000 to buy additionA. tools to enlarge his business.

loans.use: To buy additional tools

loans.name: Inna

texts.en:
Inna B. sells beer and groundnut paste and is requesting a loan to stock bags of charcoal to sell. Inna is 33 years old and is married to a teacher. She has 3 children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a charcoal store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad is a young Palestinian man living in Zieta village. He owns a greenhouse where he grows many vegetables. His monthly average income is around 600 USD, which is considered around average, especially as he is living in a village instead of a city (where the cost of living is higher). Mohammad is planning to get married, so he is in the process of building his own house. The house is built, but he hasn't finalized the finishings so he has requested 2,000 USD from FATEN to finish preparing his house.

Mohammad appears in this picture taken at the FATEN office.

loans.use: To finish constructing his house

loans.name: Kamel

texts.en: Kamel repairs appliances such as air conditioners, refrigerators and washers.  He's 22 years old and he has doing this kind of work for the past four years. Kamel intends to use the $1,200 from this loan to buy used appliances and perform maintenance on them in order to sell them and make a good income.

loans.use: To buy used appliances.

loans.name: Arewa

texts.en: Arewa lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells groceries in her house. She is happy with her business because her customers pay cash when they come to purchase her groceries. Arewa has been in this business for a long time. Arewa is 45 years old and married with 5 children. She is a friendly woman and hardworking. Arewa wants to increase the prosperity of her family and that of her business. She hopes for a loan in the amount of 70,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Khaled

texts.en: Khaled has owned a coffee shop since 2005. He’s 31 years old. Today, Khaled is requesting to borrow $1,000 to buy merchandise; this loan will help him keep up his business activities by increasing his sales as well as his income.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Jihad

texts.en: Jihad has owned an aluminum shop since 2005, with a previous 15 years of experience in this market. He's 30 years old. He is asking for a loan of $1,200 to invest in buying more merchandise and appliances for his shop, to meet the demands of his clients.

loans.use: Buying more merchandise and appliances

loans.name: Lane Kuru Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'Lane Kuru' Group. 'Lane Kuru' is a Temne phrase meaning “believe in God”. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni city who have come to SMT/Kiva to seek their very first loan. They are requesting a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to expand their businesses.

Wara T. (left) is the leader of this group. Wara was born in Masongbo, on the outskirts of Makeni. She is now approximately forty-five years of age. She is married and has four children who are all grown-up and on their own.

Wara sells 'gara lappers' (locally dyed cloth). She has got ten years of experience in this business. With her share of the loan, she will invest in her business. She will use the loan to buy lengths of white cotton, inks, caustic soda, and a bowl that she will used in her 'gara'-dyeing work.

loans.use: Buy working materials like lengths of white cotton, caustic soda, powder, inks and a basin

loans.name: Mohamad Ali

texts.en: Mohamad Ali has owned a gym since 1999 in his town. He's 29 years old. He decided to open this kind of business because he really likes all kinds of sports and with his long experience he will be helpful to other people. Today, Mohamad Ali is applying for a loan of $700 to buy specific equipment for his gym in order to attract more clients.

loans.use: To buy specific gym equipment

loans.name: Konga

texts.en:
Konga M. is currently in the business of selling dried fish in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase cooking oil and onions to sell.  Konga is 39 years old and is married with a husband who is a peasant. She has four children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase a motor boat for her husband for fishing.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase cooking oil and onions to sell

loans.name: Naji

texts.en: Naji has owned an internet cafe in his town since 2004. He’s 50 years old and the father of three children, two of whom are unemployed. Today, Naji is requesting to borrow $1,200 to buy more computer games and programs to attract more children and students and make a good profit.

loans.use: buy more computer games and programs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase musical instruments for DJ systems.

loans.name: American Group

texts.en:
These are members of the 'American' Group. They are small-scale entrepreneurs in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. They have applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to further strengthen their businesses. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses both in size and quality. Consequently, they will make more sales and better profit. As their profit-to-sales-margin increases, they will better support themselves and their children.

The leader of this group, Mohamed K., is on the left. Mohamed was born in Makeni. He is age thirty-seven, divorced with four children. His children are attending schools – three in secondary school and one in primary school.

Mohamed sells soft drinks, cigarettes, mints and chewing gum. Mohamed has got four years of experience in this type of business. With his share of the loan, he will invest in his business by buying more crates of drinks, cartons of mints, chewing gum, and cigarettes.

loans.use: Buy drinks, mints, chewing gum, and cigarettes

loans.name: Samir

texts.en: Samir has worked as a taxi driver since 2007 to raise his three children. He works hard to earn income to help satisfy the needs of the family. Today, Samir is asking to borrow $1,200 to perform maintenance on his car.

loans.use: To perform maintenance on his car

loans.name: Monika

texts.en:
Monika T. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and tomatoes in the market and is requesting a loan to rent a store and buy timber to sell.  Monika is 31 years old and married to a businessman. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a  shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Rent a store and buy timber to sell

loans.name: Mess Road Group

texts.en:
These are members of the 'Mess Road' Group. They are small-scale entrepreneurs in Makeni city who have come to SMT/Kiva for the first time to seek a loan in order to boost their businesses. Each is seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 to expand his/her business.

The leader of this group is Mamusu K. on the left. Mamusu was born in Makeni about forty-five years ago. She is married and has six children. Her husband is a driver and her children are attending primary and secondary schools respectively.

Mamusu bakes and sells bread. She also supplies flour and palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil) to other businesswomen in town. Mamusu has been a businesswoman for fifteen years now. With her share of the loan, she will further expand her business by buying more bags of flour and more gallons of palm-oil.

loans.use: Buy flour and palm-oil

loans.name: Adama

texts.en: Adama sells groceries and baby things in her shop to make a living. She has been in this business for four years. Her greatest joy in her business is the profits that she makes. Adama is a single lady without a child. She is 29 years old. Adama is very enthusiastic and optimistic about the future growth of her business. She hopes for a loan of 70,000 NGN to purchase more groceries and baby things to sell. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and baby things to sell

loans.name: Tayagba Group

texts.en:
Here are Nanah B., Fanta K., Isatu B., and Kadiatu K.. They are small-scale entrepreneurs in the northern city of Makeni. They are seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to add more goods to their businesses. In this way, they will be able to make more sales and better profit. Consequently, they can better support their children in terms of feeding, clothing and in their academic pursuits.

Nanah B. (left) is the leader of this group. She is thirty-two years of age, born in Kamakwe, a town in northern Sierra Leone. Nanah is married with three children. Her husband is a vehicle mechanic and her children are attending schools – one in secondary school and the other two in primary school. Nana sells toothpaste, soap, torch-light/push lights, batteries, mints, chewing gum, etc. Nanah has been in this type of business for twenty years now. With her share of the loan, she will invest in her business by buying cartons of toothpaste, batteries, soaps and chewing gum.

loans.use: Buy cartons of toothpaste, batteries, mints, soaps and chewing gum

loans.name: Adenike

texts.en: Adenike sells foodstuffs at retail prices to her customers in her house. She is happy because she does not have to pay for stall rent. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. She lives in Lagos state, Nigeria. Adenike is happily married with seven children. She is 33 years old. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Caritina

texts.es:
La señora Caritina  con 55 años de edad esta casada. Su cónyuge tiene 55 años de edad, es albañil constructor. La pareja tiene un hijo mayor de edad, los mismos  viven  en la ciudad de Pilar, en casa propia, en el barrio 12 Octubre de esta ciudad, la residencia cuenta con  todas las comodidades de primera necesidad para el hogar. Dentro del predio de la cas a en un salón funciona un taller carpintería donde se realiza trabajos de todo tipo, desde compostura hasta la fabricación de muebles de muy buena calidad según algunos cliente quienes son de de lugar aledaños como también del extranjero (Argentina). 
Se dedican a esta actividad hace más de 13 años, y cuentan con todos los materiales requeridos para el trabajo dentro de la casa como también para trabajos a domicilio fuera de la misma. Desde que empezó a operar con nuestra institución ha obtenido mejores rendimientos en su tarea ya que siempre les brindamos nuestro apoyo en todo emprendimiento que la señora tenía en mente, es por eso que ella se siente muy agradecida con la Fundación Paraguaya. El apoyo que ella tiene de su familia es fundamental para el desarrollo de su actividad. 

Solicita el crédito para comprar madera para realizar trabajos para una empresa que siempre le realiza pedidos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Caritina is 55 years old and married. Her spouse is also 55 years old and a construction worker. The couple has one child who is of age and they live in the city of Pilar, in their own home, in the neighborhood “October 12.” Their home has all of the basic necessities a home requires. They have a carpenter’s workshop on their property where they do all sorts of work from repairs to making furniture, which according to customers (who come from the area and abroad like Argentina), is of high quality. They have been doing this for more than thirteen years, and have all of the necessary materials for work inside the home and outside. Since they started working with our organization, they have obtained better yields for their work since we always offer our support in all enterprises the Mrs. has in mind. This is why she is grateful to Fundación Paraguaya. The support she receives from her family is also fundamental to the success of her business. She is asking for a loan to buy wood to do jobs for a company that always orders from them.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase wood to make furniture.

loans.name: Life Time Group

texts.en:
Patience V. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Life Time. She is 32 years old and married with two children aged 4 and 9 years old. Neither of them are schooling due to poverty. She is a high school graduate but could not continue to university due to lack of financial support.

Patience and her family live and work in the Barrolle community, Gbarnga City, the capital of Bong County, Liberia.

Her business is the sale of general goods. She buys general goods wholesale and sells retail to residents of her community in Gbarnga the capital of Bong County, Liberia. Patience has been running this business for two years and hopes to graduate from this small business to a better one.

The high price of goods and cost of transportation from wholesalers to her business site are really a difficulty for Patience’s business.

She needs this loan to purchase more goods to improve her business. Patience dreams of giving her family the best support.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to improve business.

loans.name: Tuna

texts.en:
Tuna R. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs in a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase sodas and beer to sell.  Tuna is 43 years old and is married to a businessman. She has four children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a clinical pharmacy.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase sodas and beer to sell.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria S. is currently in the business of selling mobile phones and is requesting a loan to stock more phones to sell.  Victoria is 25 years old and is married to an electrical engineer. She has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up an internet cafe.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more phones to sell

loans.name: Crystal Business Group

texts.en:
Aletha N. S. is a leader of a group of 5 borrowers called Crystal Business. She is 35 years old, married with 7 children aged 2-14 years old. Their educational levels are from 1st to8th grade. She also cares for 3 siblings.

Aletha is a 10th grade drop-out due to lack of financial support.She and her family live and work in the Civil compound community in Gbarnga city, the capital of Bong county,Liberia.
Her business is the sales of general goods.She buys general goods wholesale and sells retail to residents of her community in Gbarnga the capital of Bong County, Liberia.  Aletha has been running this business for 2 years, and is hoping to improve her business. The high price of goods and cost of transportation from wholesalers is really a difficulty for Aletha’s business. She requests this loan to purchase more supplies of goods to improve business. 

Aletha dreams of empowering her children for a better future.

loans.use: to purchase more supplies of goods to improve business.

loans.name: Virgilio

texts.es:
El Señor Virgilio es comerciante de la zona de Pilar, su negocio se halla situada en el km 1 de esta ciudad, trabajo con el ramo más de 8 años, realizando la venta de mercaderías en la zona, el mismo posee 35 años de edad, es soltero, vive en su casa propia hace varios años. El Señor además de la carnicería que posee también se dedica a la compra de ganado ya que le genera mejores ganancias en el momento de faenar sus animales.

Posee todas las comodidades necesarias para el bienestar de su casa, y también cuenta con todas las herramientas de trabajo para su carnicería. Don Virgilio agradece a la Fundación Paraguaya por la ayuda brindada ya mediante la misma pudo mejorar en gran medida la calida de sus productos y de sus servicios, mediante esto también pudo mejora las ventas de su negocio.

El cliente solicitó el préstamo para comprar mercaderías, ya que se le presentó una oportunidad de negocio a buen precio.
texts.en:
Mr. Virgilio is a shopkeeper in the Pilar zone. His business can be found 1km from the city. He has worked with this branch for over 8 years, selling merchandise within the zone. He, himself, is 35 years old, single and lives in a house he has owned for several years. As well as the butchers shop that he owns, he also buys cattle which generates further income at slaughter. He has all the conveniences needed for the wellbeing of his household and also finds himself with all the tools of the butchers trade. Don Virgilio is grateful to the “Fundación Paraguaya” for all the help it has given him and hopes that by similar means he can improve the quality of his products and services and thus the sales of his business. He is requesting the loan in order to buy merchandise, now that he has the opportunity to negotiate a good price.

Translated from Spanish by Emma Felten, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy meat

loans.name: Yovanna

texts.es:
La socia YOVANNA hace un año que pertenece al banco comunal “PROSPERIDAD”  

Nuestra socia es una humilde madre de familia, tiene 28 años de edad, es conviviente y tienen una hija. La Hija Karol tiene 3 años y estudia en el jardín. Ellas viven en la ciudad imperial del Cusco. 

La socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con el negocio de venta de condimentos y  distribución de los mismos en los mercados minoristas. Ya son varios años que trabaja en el negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a su familia. La socia requiere el préstamo para implementar una cabina de Internet en la plaza mayor del distrito de San Jerónimo. Ella desea comprar con los 1200 dólares suministros de computadoras.      

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Yovanna has been a member of the communal bank “Prosperidad” (Prosperity) for one year. The member is a humble mother of one daughter, 28 years old and in a common-law relationship. Her daughter Karol is 3 years old and in kindergarten. They live in the imperial city of Cusco. The member varies her housework activities with a business selling and distributing condiments in the retail markets. She has been working in this business for several years and it is going very well thanks to all the determination she puts into her work. The member is a hard working woman and learns quickly in order to help her family progress. The member requires a loan to start an internet café in the main plaza in the San Jerónimo district. With the 1200 dollar loan, she will buy computer supplies. The member is very grateful for the opportunity brought by these means and promises to comply with the repayment timeline.

Translated from Spanish by Emma Felten, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The member requires the loan in order to start an internet cafe.

loans.name: Titilayo

texts.en: Titilayo is a mother of 4 and she is 43 years old. She sells foodstuffs and detergent from her house in Lagos state, Nigeria. She is a hard working woman and she is determined to excel in her business and family life. Titilayo is requesting a loan amount of NGN 70,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and detergent to sell. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa.  She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and detergent to sell

loans.name: Antony

texts.en: K. has been running a butcher shop for the last 15 years. He also does farming to supplement his income. He is married and has six children and he is the sole breadwinner for the family. His butcher shop is located within the kakamega market. He employs 1 person and his butcher shop serves clients within the market and its environs. He is requesting for a loan of KES. 40,000 to purchase more beef cattle. He describes himself as a visionary and hardworking person.

loans.use: to purchase beef cattle

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James K. is a 38 year old gentleman who is married to Eunice Musenya. They have four children who are all of school going age. James has been running a boutique in Naivasha town for the last four years.

He was introduced to KADET by a friend who is a client. This is James’ second loan with KADET. He used his first loan to move the business to more a decent premise. With this second loan James intends to improve the boutique by adding more stock in readiness for the Christmas season when he expects to make a great sale.

He hopes to convert his retail shop into wholesale in the nearest future.

loans.use: To improve his clothes boutique by adding more  variety and stock

loans.name: Sherifatu

texts.en:
Sherifatu is 48 years old and married with 6 children.

Sherifatu sells charcoal and firewood to make a living in her community in Lagos State, Nigeria. The demands for her charcoal and firewood are high because there are people in her community that cannot afford to use a stove or cooking cylinders. She hopes to be a distributor of firewood in the future.

She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more charcoal and firewood to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal and firewood to sell

loans.name: Nancy Yessenia

texts.es:
Nuestra socia YESSENIA es una madre de familia, tiene 32 años de edad, es casada, tienen dos hijos: Santiago tiene 6 años y estudia en el colegio y esta en el nivel primario y Esteban tiene 4 años y esta en el jardín. Ellos viven en la ciudad imperial del Cusco. Ella pertenece al banco comunal “MANOS JUNTAS” de la Asociación Arariwa.

La socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con el negocio de servicio de salón de belleza, de Internet y de lavandería. Tiene también una tienda de librería donde vende productos como libros, cuadernos y regalos. Ya son varios años que trabaja en el negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a su familia. La socia requiere el préstamo para aumentar el capital del negocio comprando más regalos que sean alusivos a la navidad  como peluches, adornos y mucha más.  
  
La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Yessenia is 32, married, and has two children. Santiago is 6, and he goes to elementary school. Esteban is 4, and he is in preschool. They live in the imperial city of Cusco. She belongs to the Manos Juntas communal bank of the Arariwa Association. She alternates her activities between the household, her beauty salon, Internet, and laundry business. She also has a bookstore where she sells products like books, notebooks, and gifts. She has worked in the business for several years. It has gone very well for her thanks to the effort she puts into her work. She needs a loan to increase her business capital by purchasing more gifts like stuffed animals, decorations, and many more items that are hard to find at Christmas time. She is grateful for the opportunity of the loan, and she promises to pay it on time.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more gifts like stuffed animals, decorations, and much more that are hard to find at Christmas time

loans.name: John Kimani

texts.en:
John is 34 years old and married to Phylis. They have one son who is 11 years old and one daughter who is seven years old.

He has been operating a retail shop for the past six years and also farming with the support of his wife to earn other income. John was introduced to Kadet through an existing client and has had no previous loan with any other microfinance institution. He is planning to purchase a water pump to boost his farming activities. He intends to expand his business with the extra income that he hopes to generate from the shop and farm.

His future hopes and dreams are to own a hardware shop, and he describes himself as a hardworking business man.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump

loans.name: Thelesphore

texts.en:
Thelesphore is a 25-year-old single businessman. He lives in Musanze, a region of Ruhengeri, in the Northern Province of Rwanda, which is approximately two hours from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Thelesphore has been successful in his business of selling dishes and kitchenware for the past seven years. He began his career as an entrepreneur early in life. He employs three people from his community and together they work from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. every weekday. 

Thelesphore is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. He plans to use these funds to purchase more dishes and kitchenware in order to meet the growing demand from his customers. With this expansion, he will satisfy the prevailing market and in the process, increase his sales and attract more customers.

If his plans work out, Thelesphore hopes to increase his revenue and reinvest any profits in his business in order to create a strong financial base for his growing enterprise.

loans.use: To purchase more dishes and kitchenware

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella sells drinks, groceries and foodstuffs from her house and sells for long hours to enable her meet the basic needs of her home. She has been in this business for a long time.

Stella is a Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) client and she got her capital to start this business from LAPO. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. Stella hopes for a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and drinks to sell.

Stella is 26 years old and married with a child. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs, groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Beatrice Wanja

texts.en:
Beatrice is a 42 year old single mother. She is single handedly raising two daughters aged 11 years and 18 years respectively. She has been operating her green grocery for the past three years and she also does tailoring as her other source of income. Her business is located in a busy market place. Though she is a single mother she has managed to raise her children through her business (green grocer). The two children are both in secondary school and she appreciates Kadet's support in educating her children.
 
She was introduced to Kadet through a friend who is also a Kadet client.

Beatrice intends to constructs rental houses on her piece of land. Her hope and dream is to grow her business and import new clothes from Tanzania and be a distributor. Beatrice describes herself as hardworking, good leader, honest and God fearing lady.

loans.use: To buy additional grocery items for her store

loans.name: Riziki

texts.en:
Riziki is 27 years old, married with five children, and she lives in Ruhengeli, a region situated in the northern province of Rwanda.  Here, she owns a business of selling bricks.

Riziki has been a successful businesswoman in the brick business for the past 12 years and she is still going strong! She employs 10 people from her community and they work from 7 a.m. to 4 p.m. every day.  Riziki is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase supplies and additional bricks to sell. With this expansion, she hopes to satisfy the growing demand for bricks from her customers as well as attract new customers.

If her plans succeed, Riziki will be able to reinvest a portion of the revenues into the business and save some in order to ensure the financial stability of her business and to take care of her young family.

loans.use: To purchase more bricks and supplies to sell

loans.name: Ify

texts.en: Ify sells drinks and Nigerian cooked foods like moi moi (steamed bean cake), eba (cassava dough), pepper soup and beans. She loves cooking and that is why she commercialized her cooking skills to yield her money. Ify is 30 years old, married with a child. She is determined to increase the financial strength of her family. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria. She hopes for a loan of NGN 50,000 to more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs

loans.name: Gboma Group

texts.en:
Doris Tokpahis a leader of a group of 4 borrowers called Gboma. She is 43 years old, married with 4 children aged 7-22 years old; their educational levels are 3rd grade through high school graduate. She also cares for 2 siblings.

Doris is illiterate due to lack of financial support. She and her family live and works in the Vula village, Gbarnga City, the capital of Bong county, Liberia. Her business is the sale of general goods. She buys general goods wholesale and sells retail to residents of her community in Gbarnga. Doris has been running this business for 3 years, and hoping to move her business to a bigger business center.

She sells attractive goods in order to encourage customers to continue buying from her. The increase in price of goods is really a difficulty for Doris’ business. She needs this loan to purchase some goods to improve business. Doris dreams of giving her children a good educational foundation for a better future.

loans.use: To purchase some goods to improve business.

loans.name: Fabien

texts.en:
Fabien is 21 years of age and he is single. He lives in Musanze, a region of Ruhengeri, in the Northern Province of Rwanda.

Fabien has been a proven entrepreneur in the business of selling household items such as saucepans, flasks, jugs, stoves, etc. He has run his business for four successful years and employs two people from his community. Every day except Saturday he starts his work at 6 a.m. and works until 6 p.m.

Fabien is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business by purchasing more household items such as saucepans, flasks, stoves, etc. He believes that he must offer more products to his customers to better satisfy their growing demand for these items.

Fabien plans to save a portion of any profits he earns to build a stable foundation for his business and also to start saving for a family one day!

loans.use: To buy additional household items to sell

loans.name: David Muchoki

texts.en:
David is a 35-year-old man who is married to Millicent. They have one son and three daughters aged 11 years, 9 years, 1 year and 6 months. David has been operating a general shop business for the past year and he does his business at Gatukuyu shopping centre in his home town. His customers are members of the local community.

He has no loan history with other microfinance institutions. He has planned to purchase more stock for his shop. He intends to save his profit to access a bigger loan.

His future hope and dream is to open a wholesale shop. He describes himself as an ambitious man with a vision that only needs his continuous hard work.

loans.use: To add stock in his retail shop like rice, cooking oil, biscuits and many more

loans.name: Angelica

texts.es:
Nuestra socia ANGELICA es una madre D. familia, tiene 50 años D. edad, es casada, tienen dos hijos. Ellos viven en la ciudad imperial del Cusco. Ella pertenece al banco comunal “MANOS JUNTAS” D. la Asociación Arariwa.

La socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con el negocio D. distribución D. mixtura (son elementos D. papel D. forma circulas y largas que es utilizado en las fiestas). Ella distribuye a todos las tiendas minoristas la ciudad del Cusco. Ella trae el producto D. la ciudad D. Juliaca del departamento D. Puno. Ya son varios años que trabaja en el negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a su familia. La socia requiere el préstamo para aumentar el capital del negocio comprando más serpentinas D. papel. 
   
La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Angelica is 50 years old. She is married, with two children. They live in the city of Cusco. She is a member of the “Manos Juntas” [Hands Together] communal bank of the Arariwa Association.

Angelica balances her household duties with a business distributing “mixtura,” confetti in round and long shapes that is used in celebrations. She distributes to all the small stores in Cusco, as well as the city of Juliaca, in the department of Puno. She has operated this business for several years and it has gone very well, thanks to the determination she puts into her work.

Angelica is a hardworking and enterprising mother who wants her family to get ahead. She requires a loan to increase her working capital and buy more confetti. She is grateful for the opportunity provided by this means, and commits to making her payments on schedule.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase working captial and buy confetti

loans.name: Justus Kamande

texts.en:
Justus is 50 years old and married to Nelius Wambui. They have four sons and one daughter. He has been doing coffee farming for the past 29 years and also he operates a green grocery stall as his other source of income.

Justus was introduced to Kadet through marketing outreach and he has no previous credit history with any other MFI. He has applied for a loan which he is planning to use to expand and venture into different farming activities like platting maize, French beans and French peas.

He intends to buy dairy cattle with this the extra profit he generates from the farm produce and green grocery. His future hope and dream is to export his farm produce to other countries. He describes himself as a hardworking man.

loans.use: To expand farming by planting new crops like french beans and peas

loans.name: Nassim

texts.en:
Nassim is 44 years old and is married with six children between 6 and 20 years old. She lives in Musanze, which is approximately two hours drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Nassim is a hardworking businesswoman selling decorative and hygiene items. This is her tenth successful year in business! She employs three people from her community in her shop. The hours of her business are from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day of the week.

Nassim is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company so that she can purchase some additional decorative items and handicrafts to sell to her customers. With the additional sales expected due to the approaching Christmas season, she desires more products to display and offer.

Any additional profits Nassim earns will allow her to sustain her children through their studies and better provide for their basic food and health needs.

loans.use: To purchase additional decorative items and handicrafts to sell

loans.name: Norma

texts.es:
Nuestra socia NORMA es una madre de familia, tiene 37 años de edad, es casada y tiene tres hijos. Ellos viven en la ciudad imperial del Cusco. Ella pertenece al banco comunal “MANOS JUNTAS” de la Asociación Arariwa.

La socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con el negocio de venta de productos de belleza. Ella lleva un catalogo en la mano y ofrece sus productos a sus amigas, vecinas y familiares. Ella hace pedido a la tienda mayorista cuando unos de sus clientes esta interesado en el producto. Ya son varios años que trabaja en el negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a su familia. La socia requiere el préstamo para aumentar el capital haciendo más pedidos a la tienda mayorista como perfumes, aretes, collares y aretes. 
   
La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Our partner Norma is a 37-year-old mother who is married with three children. They live in the imperial city of Cusco. She belongs to the community bank “Manos Juntas” (“Hands Together”) from the Arariwa Association. The partner alternates her household activities with her business of selling beauty products. She carries a catalog with her and offers her products to her friends, neighbors, and relatives. She places orders at the wholesale store when one of her customers is interested in a product. She has worked in this business for several years and it has gone well thanks to all the determination she has put into her work. Our partner is a hardworking mother and entrepreneur who has improved the well-being of her family. She needs the loan to increase her capital, making more orders to the wholesale store for perfumes, earrings, and necklaces. She is very grateful for the opportunity presented to her by these means and for her part she promises to complete her payment according to the timeline.

Translated from Spanish by Kelley Maynard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The partner needs a loan to increase capital, placing orders to the wholesale store for perfumes, earrings, and necklaces

loans.name: Leatitia

texts.en:
Leatitia is 35 years old and is married with three children aged 3, 5 and 12 years. Leatitia and her family live in Ruhengeri, in the Northern Province of Rwanda, which is two hours drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Leatitia has been in the business of selling Irish potatoes for the past year. Though she is new in this business, she is faring quite well and she employs two people from her community. Together, they work from 6 a.m. to 4 p.m. every weekday.

Leatitia is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to buy more Irish potatoes for sale in order to make her business more competitive as well as satisfying the high demand for Irish potatoes from her customers. Through this expansion, she hopes to supply to larger markets than she was previously able to.

If this expansion succeeds, Leatitia will save funds and provide for the education and health of her three children.

loans.use: To purchase more Irish potatoes to sell

loans.name: Emmah Njoki

texts.en:
Emmah is 42 years old and a single mother with one son who is 20 years old. She has been selling second-hand clothes for the past 10 years. Her business is located in a busy and densely populated area.

Emmah was introduced to Kadet through an existing client. She has never borrowed from any other MFI before. She has applied for a loan which she is planning to use to add stock for children's clothing like dresses, trousers and t-shirts. This will enable her to compete with her competitors especially during this Christmas festive season.

Emmah intends to pay her son's college fee and later purchase a piece of land with the extra profit generated from her business. Her hope and dream is to expand her business so that she can open a big store where she can sell new clothes. Emmah is an aggressive and hardworking lady and she is also a good leader for her group with Kadet.

loans.use: To add stock for childrens clothes

loans.name: Nkieru

texts.en: Nkrieru sells electronics at wholesale and retail prices to her customers in the market. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to make more profits during this season. She is 35 years old and married with 4 children. She is a hard worker. She sells for long hours to enable her support her home. She is requesting for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more electronics to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more electronics to sell

loans.name: Santos Claudina

texts.es:
La señora SANTOS CLAUDINA M. G. tiene 45 años, vive en el distrito deL PORVENIR, provincia de Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú. Pertenece al Banco Comunal LIDERESAS EN ACCION. La socia presenta estudios hasta 6to de primaria, refiere que por falta de recursos económicos dejó de estudiar para empezar a trabajar,  es conviviente y tiene 4 hijos de los cuales 2 dependen económicamente de ella. Santos, se dedica a la atención de su tienda de comestibles.
Con su primer crédito de 300.00 nuevos soles compró andamios para su tienda.
Con este crédito de 800.00 nuevos soles comprará productos alimentitos como: arroz, aceite, leche, jugos, gaseosas, golosinas, menestras, fideos, atún, etc para surtir su tienda.
Ella sueña con poco a poco abastecer más su tienda y empezar a vender cerveza para generar mayores ingresos para la crianza y educación de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Ms. Santos Claudina M. G. is a 45-year-old woman who lives in the Porvenir district of the Trujillo province, department of La Libertad, Peru. She is a member of the Lideresas en Accion Communal Bank. Our client completed 6th grade, but states that she had to leave her studies and start working because of her lack of financial resources. She has a live-in partner and 4 children, 2 of whom still depend on her financially. Santos sells foodstuffs for a living.

With her first 300.00 PEN loan, she purchased shelves for her general store. With this 800.00 PEN loan, she will purchase goods like: rice, cooking oil, milk, juice, soft drinks, candy, legumes, noodles, tuna, etc. to restock her shop.

She dreams of restocking her store little by little, and would like to start selling beer in order to earn greater profits to raise and provide an education for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, cooking oil, milk, juice, soft drinks, candy, legumes, noodles, tuna, etc.

loans.name: Rosenne

texts.en: Rosenne has been doing tailoring for the last nine years. She makes dresses, tablecloths and also sells material. She is married and has two children. Her husband is also a businessman. Her customers are mostly ladies. Her major challenge is the seasonality in demand for clothes. She is borrowing KES 70,000 to restock her business with clothing and to buy a new sewing machine in preparation for the festive season. She is visionary and hardworking and wants to have a boutique in the future.

loans.use: To buy clothing materials and a sewing machine

loans.name: Chiwe

texts.en: Chiwe sells hair extensions and hair cream at retail prices in her shop. She is not a hair stylist but she sells hair materials to make a living. She is happy because the high season is here and she hopes to make more sales during this season. She is 33 years old, married with a child. Her child is doing well in school. Chiwe is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria. She hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more hair extensions and hair cream to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and cream to sell

loans.name: Justina

texts.es:
La señora Justina es socia del Banco Comunal “3 de Mayo II” desde hace 3
años, vive en el distrito y provincia de Puno, departamento de Puno, tiene
38 años de edad, es casada y tiene 3 hijos. Ella estudió primaria completa,
se dedica a la venta de comida al paso. En sus ratos libres se dedica a la
producción de artesanías (tejido).

Justina nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento
Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, pudo incrementar su capital, para
poder comprar víveres para la preparación de sus alimentos.

Ella requiere un crédito de S/. 600.00 nuevos soles, con el cual podrá
comprar papas, carne molida, panes, etc. Para la elaboración de sus
alimentos.

Su sueño para el futuro es tener su tienda de abarrotes y que sus hijos sean
profesionales.

Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal son los ahorros.
texts.en:
Justina has been a member of the “May 3rd II” cooperative bank for 3 years. She lives in the Puno province, is 38 years old, married, and has 3 children. She completed her primary school studies and dedicates herself to being a street food vendor. In her spare time, she also makes knitted crafts. Justina tells us that she used her first loan of 300.00 Peruvian soles from Manuela Ramos to increase her working capital, in order to buy ingredients for making her food. She is requesting a loan of 600.00 soles in order to buy potatoes, ground beef, breads, etc. Her dreams for the future are to have a grocery store and to see her children become professionals. What she appreciates most about her cooperative bank is the ability to save.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase ground beef, breads, sausages, potatoes.

loans.name: Noelia Bernarda

texts.es: Noelia Bernarda tiene la edad de 37 años, es una mujer casada. Tiene 1 hijo a su cargo. La actividad económica es la venta de mercadería en general. Hace más de 4 años que se dedica a este negocio, por lo que inicio con esfuerzo propio anteriormente no tenia lo suficientes recursos para tener su proprio negocio, era uno de los trabajos que más le gusto ya que lograba conversar con sus clientes y conocía las necesidades de cada uno de ellos, por lo que fue una manera de mejorar los pocos ingresos necesarios para su familia. Manteniendo ese entusiasmo para sus clientes. Es así que decide realizar este financiamiento con el fin de invertir en su negocio para capital de trabajo para pantalones, camisas, shorts, faldas vestidos y algunos trajes por lo que se acerca la temporada navideña y tiene muchos pedidos. El deseo de ella es que su negocio aumente para beneficio de su familia.
texts.en:
Noelia Bernarda is 37 years old and married. She takes care of one son. Her economic activity is the sale of general merchandise. She has been working in this business for the past four years, which she started with her own effort. Previously she didn't have enough resources to start her own business. This was one of the jobs she has enjoyed the most because she is able to converse with her customers and knows each of their needs. This was a way to increase the little income necessary for her family. She’s enthusiastic for her customers. She is requesting this financing to invest in working capital for her business such as pants, shirts, shorts, skirts, dresses, and some suits since the holiday season is approaching and she has many orders. Her wish is to improve her business for the benefit of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Esteban Riojas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Yrma Alvina

texts.es:
La señora  YRMA ALVINA R. R. tiene 50 años, vive en el distrito del PORVENIR, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad – Perú. La socia tiene estudios hasta 5to. de  secundaria, tiene 3 hijos de los cuales uno depende económicamente de ella.
Yrma se dedica a  la crianza de pollos, gallinas y cuyes en su casa para posteriormente venderlos en el mercado o realizar polladas (venta de pollo).
Con su primer crédito de 300.00 nuevos soles compró alimentos para los pollos y gallinas.
Con este crédito de 400.00 nuevos soles comprará alimento para los patos, gallinas y cuyes como: engorde, panca, alimento balanceado y alfalfa y también comprará pollos bebes para su crianza.
Yrma sueña con tener su tienda de comestible en su casa.
texts.en:
YRMA ALVINA R. R. is 50 years old and lives in PORVENIR, located in the Trujillo province of La Libertad – Perú. She studied through the 5th year of secondary school, and has 3 children who depend on her financially. Yrma dedicates herself to raising chickens and guinea pigs at her home, to later sell at the market or to make chicken dishes. With her first loan of 300.00 Peruvian soles she bought feed for her chickens. With this loan of 400 soles, she will buy feed for her ducks, chickens and guinea pigs such as: panca, balanced feed, and alfalfa. She will also buy baby chicks to raise. Yrma dreams of having her food store in her home.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy balanced feed for her ducks, chickens and guinea pigs.

loans.name: Rosa Maritza

texts.es:
Rosa es una mujer emprendedora y perseverante, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa región de Ucayali, tiene 37 años, ella se dedica a la venda de productos de belleza por catálogo y paralelamente brinda servicio de alquiler de motocar.

Rosa tiene cuatro hijos de los cuales uno es mayor de edad, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo quien es mecánico de maquinaria pesada. Forma parte del Banco Comunal “Juntas hasta el final” desde hace cinco años.
El primer crédito que recibió fue de 300 soles, que lo utilizó para comprar productos de belleza y venderlos a sus conocidos. 
En la actualidad Rosa necesita un crédito de 3000 soles que será utilizado para comprar un motocar de segundo uso. 
La meta de Rosa es comprar un motocar nuevo para mejorar sus ingresos económicos.
texts.en:
Rosa is a very enterprising and persevering woman. She lives in the Pucallpa region of Ucayali, and is 37 years old. She dedicates herself to selling beauty products from catalog and, concurrently, she provides a car rental service. Rosa has four children, of whom one is now grown. She counts on the support of her husband, who is a heavy machinery mechanic. She has been part of the “Together Until the End” cooperative bank for five years. The first loan she received was for 300 soles, which she used to buy beauty products to sell to her acquaintances. Currently, Rosa needs a loan of 3,000 soles to buy a used motocar. Rosa’s goal is to use the new motocar to improve her income.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a second used motocar.

loans.name: Caminando Hacia El Progreso 3 & 4 Group

texts.en:
Sofia, 60, is a borrower who lives near San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Caminando Hacia el Progreso (Walking Towards Progress), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in the group.

Sofia lives in El Puerto, a small town northwest of San Pedro. She has two children, one of whom still lives at home with her husband. They live in a house made from cement blocks with a tin roof, a significant improvement over the wooden houses of many neighbors. Sofia has used profits from her colmado (small corner store) to build this house, a significant achievement and proof of an expanding business. El Puerto is not an easy place to live: few medical facilities, large distances to nearest towns, little access to electricity, and no potable water access can cripple a population. Despite these difficulties, Sofia and her group have found stability in their loans and look forward to continuing to develop their businesses and community.

Sofia will be using this loan, her ninth with Esperanza International, to buy additional merchandise for her store, including bread, juices, and soft drinks. She said that before having loans, it was easy for her and other group members to fail in their businesses because they did not have enough cash flow. Now, however, she and the others in her group have thriving businesses. She is very grateful for past support and excited for the possibilities in the future. Thank you for lending to Sofia and the Caminando Hacia el Progreso group!

loans.use: Bread, juices, and refreshments

loans.name: Omolara

texts.en: Omolara sells hair extensions and hair cream at retail prices in her shop. She is not a hair stylist but she sells hair materials to make a living. She is happy because the high season is here and she hopes to make more sales during this season. She is 33 years old; married with 4 children. Her children are doing well in school. Omolara is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She hopes for the loan of NGN 120,000 to purchase more hair extensions and hair cream to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and cream to sell

loans.name: Ghetelemu Group

texts.en:
Aloysius D. is the leader of a group of four borrowers called the Ghetelemu Group. He is 43 years old and single. He has four children aged 9 to 18 years old, and their educational levels range from kindergarten through twelfth grade. He also cares for three of his siblings. Aloysius is a high school graduate but could not continue to university due to lack of financial support. He lives and works in the Gbartala community, about 20 kilometers from Gbarnga City, which is the capital of Bong County, Liberia.

His business is a tea shop. He owns this tea shop, where he sells tea, bread, coffee, fried eggs and other food items to residents of his community. Aloysius has been running this business for three years, and is hoping to expand his business to a bigger shop where customers can be comfortable while they eat. Aloysius needs this loan to purchase more supplies to improve his business. He dreams of giving his children a quality education.

loans.use: To purchase more supplies to improve his business

loans.name: Vision Plus Group

texts.en:
Brigitte K. is the leader of a community bank named “Vision Plus,” which is composed of 32 entrepreneurs united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC with the goal of developing their businesses.

Brigitte is 42 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are in school. Brigitte currently sells spices. She has been in business since 1999, when she started out selling doughnuts. After learning through her friend about IMF HOPE RDC’s loan program, she decided to join one of its groups in July of 2008. Brigitte has already received four loans from IMF HOPE RDC that she repaid in full. Currently, her business brings in a profit of $20 per week. With her next loan she is planning to purchase more spices to increase the inventory of her business. Brigitte’s dream is to be a provider of spices in her area. Her spice business is located in northern Kinshasa, which is the most the most densely populated region of the city.

loans.use: To increase inventory in order to reinforce her working capital

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Rina

texts.es:
La señorita Rina es socia del Banco Comunal “Las Kantutas” desde hace 2 años del distrito y provincia de Puno, departamento de Puno, tiene 29 años de edad, es soltera y no tiene hijos. Ella estudiò superior completo, se dedica a la compra y venta de productos de belleza.

Rina nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, pudo incrementar su capital para poder comprar cremas, perfumes, labiales.

Ella solicitará un crédito  de S/. 600.00 nuevos soles, con el cual podrá comprar perfumes, cremas, labiales, rimels, etc.

Su sueño para el futuro es formar su propia empresa de restaurants turísticos.
