Benilda A. is from the village of Binuanagan, in Misamis Oriental. She is 45 years old.  Benilda is married and has 1 adult children. To make a living, Benilda owns & operates a sari-sari (general) store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes  from selling food & essentials in the local community. Benilda has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Benilda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Benilda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Benilda is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to expand her business. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Benilda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Uuganbayar

texts.en:
Uuganbayar L. is 22 years old and lives with his wife and two infant children in Uvs province, one of Mongolia's westernmost provinces. His two sons are just 1 and 2 years old. His wife mostly takes care of their two children and helps with her husband's business when she has free time. Uuganbayar graduated from secondary school in 2007 and married to his wife. Since then, he has started making shoes for locals. He is also sells second-hand clothes in the local black market. He says that his retail market has been improving and the clothes he sells are in high demand. He says that he would like to expand his business selling second-hand clothes. He says that he is determined to make his business succeed and to provide to his two little sons a happy life.

He requests a loan to purchase more second-hand clothes for his business. About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All§ors[]=All®ions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: to purchase more second-hand clothes

loans.name: Khim

texts.en:
Mrs. Khim O., 32, is married to 34-year-old Choun Hon, and they have two children who are students and dependent on their parents’ income. This couple relies on making and selling rattan cupboards. They weave at least ten sets of rattan before they start selling using their old horse and cart.

Recently, their existing horse became too old and can’t continue to work for their business and this affects their current income. Hence, Khim O. would like to seek a Kiva loan through HKL in order to replace her old horse.

loans.use: To replace her old horse

loans.name: Gantsetseg

texts.en:
Gantsetseg G. is 40 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in Uvs province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. Her two daughters are 5 and 15 years old and go to local secondary schools. Gantsetseg runs a small food cafeteria in the town. She has been running her cafeteria since 1999 and it is located in the busy area of the local black market. Her cafeteria is quite well-recognized in the black market and she is always busy with her customers. She says that she would like to purchase the real estate in which she operates. Currently, she pays high rent and she would like to own the building to operate more profitably in the future. Gantsetseg requests a loan to purchase necessary ingredients and supplies for her cafeteria business. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.
To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.
To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase necessary ingredients and supplies

loans.name: Tsagaanbandi

texts.en:
Tsagaanbandi T. is 30 years old and lives with his wife and three children in the Hovd province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. His three children are ages 5 to 12. Tsagaanbandi and his wife both have small businesses in their respective fields. His wife sells various vegetables at the local food market and Tsagaanbandi does transporting with his truck and small car. He has worked as a truck driver for the last twenty years. After the collapse of the command economy in late 1990, he purchased the truck he used to drive for a company and since then he has been doing business with his own truck. In the winter, he uses his truck to carry coal from countryside to the town for retail. With his profit, he was able to buy a small old car that he now uses as a cab for additional income.

He requests a loan to purchase more coal and more vegetables for his family businesses. About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All§ors[]=All®ions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: to purchase more coal and more vegetables

loans.name: Purevtogtoh

texts.en:
Purevtogtoh is 41 years old aN. lives with his wife aN. three childreN.iN.Ovorhangai province, oN. of Mongolia's central provinces. Al of his three daughters are high school students. He has a small truckiN. business. He currently owN. a truck aN. he uses his truck to carry various cargo amoN. nearby towN.. He says that his truck is the maiN.source of income for his family aN. he is well-knowN.for his reliability aN. good service amoN. local customers. With earnings from his business, Purevtogtoh pays for his childreN.s tuitioN.aN. household expenses. Purevdorj is a humble aN. hard workiN. person.  He requests a loaN.to purchase necessary accessories for his car. 

About XacBaN.
XacBaN. was founded iN.2001, aN. listed its first loaN.oN.Kiva iN.January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organizatioN.iN.Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operatioN.. XacBaN. has the vision, scale aN. innovatioN.to develop aN. implemeN. new solutioN. to poverty. It is currently utiliziN. Kiva’s 0% lendiN. interest rate to returN.9% of interest paid from borrowers to them iN.the form of a savings accouN. at the eN. of their loaN.. This not only allows borrowers to gaiN.financially, but also encourages them to save.

To leN. to more MongoliaN.borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryStriN.=Mongolia&status=fundRaisiN.&gender=All&sectors[]=All&regioN.[]=All&sortBy=ExpiriN.+Soon

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for his vehicle

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Sam K., age 40, owns and operates a handicraft business whose main activity is selling rattan cupboard. He sells rattan that his wife weaves or he orders from other weavers who live in the village. He uses his horse cart as transportation and it takes a week to sell all his rattan. Sam K. has been facing difficulties transporting his rattan because his horse cart is slow and that affects how he can satisfy the needs of his customers. Because of this problem, Sam K. decided to request a loan to purchase a motorcycle to which he will attach his existing cart, which he will use to transport his product more quickly.

Note: Sam K. was busy selling his product when the photo taken, so his wife is pictured instead.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Enhbayar

texts.en:
Enhbayar N. is 41 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Hovd province, one of western provinces. His three oldest daughters go to secondary school in the town and the youngest daughter is 5 years old and goes to a local kindergarten. Enhbayar is a trained welder. He has been doing welding work for the last ten years. Besides his welding work, he sells meat including mutton and beef at the local food market. His meat selling business is actually the main source of family income. His wife also helps in selling meat. His dream for his family is to have their own piece of land where they can live because currently they live on rented land. He is requesting a loan to purchase more meat for his business. 

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All&sectors[]=All&regions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: to purchase more meat

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy A. is from the village of Barandias, Pangantucan Bukidnon. She is 47 years old. Joy is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Joy owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (general) store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & essentials in the local community. Joy has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Joy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Joy is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to expand her business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Joy from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna U. is from the village of Maramag , Bukidnon. She is 33 years old, married, and has 2 grown children. To make a living, Edna owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. The primary source of income for the business comes from selling snacks & other delicacies like cassava and hotcakes in the local community. Edna has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Edna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells. Edna is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Edna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to further improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Batmagnai

texts.en:
Batmagnai Y. is 40 years old.  He lives with his spouse and three teenage children in Uvs province, one of the western provinces. All of his children go to a local secondary school. 

Batmagnai has a small shoe-making business with his wife. He is a talented and locally recognized shoemaker who has been making traditional shoes for women and men with his wife since 2006. They mostly make warm shoes for cold seasons. In winter, many locals purchase their shoes. Local herders and small business owners who work outside during cold winters absolutely need their warm shoes. 

Batmagnai says that he would like to expand his business into a small shoe shop where he would have shoe-making machinery and a shop to sell his products. He is requesting a loan to purchase the materials necessary for shoe-making. Batmagnai and his wife Altanzul are pictured above. 

About XacBank:

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All&sectors[]=All&regions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: to purchase the materials necessary for shoe-making

loans.name: Perfecta

texts.en:
Perfecta U. is from the village of Maramag, Bukidnon. She is 55 years old, widowed, and has 1 grown child. To make a living, Perfecta owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The primary source of income for the business comes from selling food & daily-use products in the local community. Perfecta is just starting her new business; prior to this she had an alacarte (grilled chicken) business in their village.

In 2009, Perfecta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Perfecta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Perfecta is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Perfecta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated through the loan to further improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Mrs. Sam Y., 51, owns a large plantation which she inherited from her grandparents. She and her husband have three children, one of whom is married. Two of their daughters are employed: one has been working in the sewing industry for years and the other is a rattan weaver. 

On her farmland, Sam Y. and her husband plant potatoes and other crops, which they sell. Besides growing crops, her husband is skilled at making wooden beds.  He wants to use his knowledge to earn more income for his family, but he doesn’t have enough money to start a business. Therefore, Sam Y. has decided to borrow money on Kiva for her husband to use as capital to buy planks and carpentry equipment so that he can begin making beds for sale.

loans.use: to buy planks and carpentry equipment to begin making beds for sale

loans.name: Som

texts.en:
Mrs. Som L., age 50, is pictured with her son at their house. To earn a living, Som L. cultivates a rice crop as well as raising some poultry. She was married, but her husband died of senility years ago and has left four children. Two of them have an occupation and the other two are unemployed.

Som L.’s employed children face difficulties with traveling. They go to work by a taxi or walking because they have no vehicle for riding purposes. To solve this obstacle, Som L. would like to request a loan to add to her savings to buy an old motorbike for her kids to use to commute to their work locations.

loans.use: To buy an old motorbike for her children's commute

loans.name: Nao

texts.en: The two people shown in the picture are Mrs. Nao Y and her husband. This couple earns a living by making and selling rattan cupboards. They have two school-aged children and live together in a medium sized wooden house located in the Kompong Tom province. Nao Y is taking out her loan to buy a cart to harness to her cow, which she will use as transportation.

loans.use: To buy a cart to harness to her cow

loans.name: Mrs. Sopheap Srey Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank consists of fifteen people and is located in Khnar Rung village in Takeo province. All the members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Sopheap S. is the president of the village bank, selected by the members. She is a pig breeder in the local village. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it.  She decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets and pig food for her current business. Her husband, Mr. So S., is a motorbike taxi driver who makes a small income to support the family. Mrs. Sopheap S. child works repairing cars.

loans.use: Buying more piglets and pig food for her business.

loans.name: Svay

texts.en: Svay H. is an older woman and the widowed mother of three children. Two of them are married and they all have jobs. Svay H. sells a few groceries to her neighbors and also takes time to braid traditional mats to sell. Svay H. needs a loan to increase the inventory of her grocery business.

loans.use: To increase the inventory of her grocery business

loans.name: Lisette

texts.en:
Lisette R. is a resident of Talim Island, Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is 36 years old and wife to Nelson, a secretary, who is also 36 years old. She has given birth to two children: Leen Heart, 5 years old, a nursery student, and Lhinel, 12 years old, a high school student. Lisette hopes to give a decent life to her family, especially her two daughters.

Lisette is engaged in a fishing business. She has a fish cage where she raises small fish until they grow and are prepared for harvest. The business seems to be cost-effective and sound, and she wants to invest more in it. She is requesting a loan of Php 20,000. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for 200 meters of fish net, bamboo, and some for labor.

Lisette is cheerful that her business will grow and she can earn more income to save in preparation for her children’s future, especially their education fees. She also aspires to having more fish cages in order to breed more fish since that means better earnings.

loans.use: To purchase fishnet, V-net, bamboo and to pay for labor

loans.name: Saroem

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroem L. is a villager from Damnak village in Takeo province. She is a duck breeder. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more ducks and duck food.

Mrs. Saroem L. is a widow with seven children. Two of her children are working in a garment factory, one works for a small company, and the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy more ducks and duck food

loans.name: Saven

texts.en:
Mrs. Saven A. (60 years old) and her husband, Mr. Pouk Nov (62 years old), have been married since 1970 and have six children. They are living on an island in the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. Phnom Penh is the capital city of Cambodia. Although the couple is elderly, they are still strong enough to work.

Saven and her husband are farmers and they grow vegetables and rice. In the past, Saven used to be a silk weaver as well. She does not have a water pumping machine, which makes farming difficult for her. She is applying for a loan of $250 to purchase a water pumping machine for use on her vegetable and rice farm.

loans.use: To purchase a water pumping machine for her farming business.

loans.name: Chreob

texts.en:
Mrs. Chreob P. lives in Tralach village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 1.5-hectare (3.75-acre) piece of land on which she cultivates rice. She is a 42-year-old widow with three children, one of whom is employed in a company while the others are attending the local school.

Now Mrs. Chreob P. is requesting a loan to add to her savings to buy a motorbike for her first child to drive to work.

loans.use: To add to her savings to buy a motorbike for her first child to drive to work

loans.name: Thol

texts.en:
Mr. Thol P., 38 years old, and his wife, Mrs. Chanthy Lac, 31 years old, (pictured together) were married in 1996 and have two children: one son and one daughter, both in school. They live along National Road Number One about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Thol and his wife are farmers. They grow corn, bitter gourd and green beans. The couple doesn’t have enough capital to maintain their farm, so Thol is asking for his first loan of $500 to pay plowing fees and to purchase fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.use: To pay plowing fees and to buy fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Thoeun N. is a villager in Tuol Svay village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she cultivates rice. On this plantation she faces an obstacle because her field has infertile soil and it is far from the irrigation system. In order to deal with this problem, she decided to ask for a loan to buy a water pump and fertilizers to support her rice field.

Mrs. Thoeun N. is 38 years old and the mother of five children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others are attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. Pun Try, is a fisherman and is shown with her in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a water pump and fertilizers to support her rice field

loans.name: Sothear

texts.en:
Mrs. Sothear Y. lives in Phnom Lun Tas village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 2.5-hectare (6.25-acre) piece of land on which she cultivates rice. Aside from this plantation, she is a pig breeder.

Since her pig-breeding business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets, pig feed, and medicine to care for them. Her husband, Mr. Mak Kunthea Ro, owns a rice mill machine. This couple has a child who is just four years old.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets, pig feed, and medicine to care for them

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en:
Loreta R. is a resident of the island village of Talim, Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is a woman of full courage and hopes to uplift from poverty. She is 35 years old and still single. She didn’t finish schooling due to her parents’ poverty since their income from business was insufficient to provide for the needs of education.

Loreta’s main dream is to uplift their standard of living. The selling of fish seems to be gainful and sound, and she desires to spend more on it.

In 2007, Loreta joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.), a micro-finance institution and Kiva partner in the Philippines, with the intention of having access to more capital for a bigger income. She is requesting a loan of Php 20,000 for her fishing business. Specifically, Php 12,000 of the loan will be used to purchase fishing net, five rolls of rope and sixteen pieces of bamboo while the balance will be used to pay the operating cost of a laborer.

Loreta is positive that her business will grow and that she will be able to earn more income to save in making their dreams come true. It will also support her parents, allow them to have a good life and to overcome poverty in their standard of living. She also wants to have her own family and own house in the upcoming years.

loans.use: To purchase fishing net, 5 rolls of rope, 16 pieces of bamboo, and to pay for labor

loans.name: Aun

texts.en:
Mrs. Aun K. is a farmer who owns 1.5 hectares of land to cultivate rice. She is also a pig breeder. Now she faces some problems with her plantation. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizers and pesticides. She will use the rest of her loan to buy piglets and pig feed for breeding.

Mrs. Aun K. is a villager in Phnouv village in Takeo province. She is 38 years old and the mother of six children: one is employed in a garment factory, while three others are attending the local school, and the rest stay at home because they are too young. Her husband, Mr. Chhin Troeun, is a palm juice collector.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizers, pesticides, piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Rin

texts.en:
Mrs. Rin Y., age 59, lives on an island in the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Phnom Penh is the capital city of Cambodia. She has three children: two sons and one daughter. One of them is married and lives in a separate home and one attends school. Her husband is a farmer.

Mrs. Rin Y. has been selling yellow coke (a kind of Cambodian cake) in front of her house for 20 years. One of her sons is a garment factory worker; he now hopes to change to a new business repairing and installing cell phone applications and MP3 and MP4 players. Through this business, he will be able to earn more income to support his family. Thus, Rin is applying for a loan of $400 to purchase a computer for her son’s business.

loans.use: To purchase a computer for her son’s business repairing cell phones

loans.name: Sary

texts.en: Mrs. Sary N. is a beef seller in the local market. She is 39 years old and the mother of three children who are attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. Sam Sophal, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice (her husband is present in the photo with her). They live in Trapaing Snaor village in Takeo province. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more beef to sell to earn more income.

loans.use: To purchase more beef to sell

loans.name: Sophan

texts.en: Mrs. Sophan P. (shown in the photo) is requesting her first loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorized hand tiller for use in their farming business. Sophan, 43, and her husband, Mr. Mab Pon, 46, have been married since 1979 and have six children: four sons and two daughters. One of their sons is married and lives outside the family home. Four others attend school. Her husband is a fisherman. Sophan sells the fish that her husband catches at the village market. Beside this business, the couple also farms. They live along National Road No. 6 about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

loans.use: To purchase a motorized hand tiller for use in a farming business

loans.name: Khin

texts.en:
Mr. Khin T. earns a living as a crop cultivator. He also depends on income from his wife’s business as a local tailor. He was not available for a photograph so his wife is pictured instead. Khin T. has been very busy with his farm and never wastes time. Recently, he has faced difficulties growing his crop because he doesn’t have enough farm supplies to best perform his farm work. Therefore, he decided to ask for a loan of $600 US to buy more farming tools.

Mr. Khin T. is 37 years of age and lives in a rural area of Phnom Penh city. He has been married for years and has four children who are no longer in school. Two of them are working in a garment factory and the other two are unemployed and dependent on him.

loans.use: To buy more farming tools

loans.name: Lo

texts.en: Mr. Lo T., 42 years old, and his wife, Mrs. Bunna Thaung, 32 years old, are farmers. They grow melon, rice and lotus. This couple doesn’t have enough capital to maintain their farm; therefore, Lo is requesting his first loan of $1,200 to pay for plowing fees and to purchase fertilizer and pesticide. Lo T. and Bunna Thaung were married in 1993 and have two children: one son and one daughter. Both of them are in school. They live along National Road No. 1 about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital ciT. of Cambodia.

loans.use: To pay for plowing fees and to buy fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Zyra Mae

texts.en:
Zyra Mae B. is from the village of Roxas Avenue Externsion, Iligan City. She is 24 years old. Zyra Mae is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Zyra Mae owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (general) store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Zyra Mae has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Zyra Mae joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zyra Mae is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Zyra Mae from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen D. C. is from the village of Roxas Avenue Extension in Iligan City. She is 45 years old. Helen is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Helen sells used oil in the local community. Helen has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Helen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Helen is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Helen's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Elenita

texts.en:
The hopes and dreams of 44-year-old Elenita R. are to provide the best for her children's education and future and, as a housewife, to support her husband in all their daily needs. They also plan to build a more accommodating and comfortable house in which to live, to expand her business to support her family and to give dedicated service to her customers. Elenita has three children, Rachel aged 20 and Lester aged 16 who are in college and Caren aged 13 who is a high school student. She is married to her caring husband, Rolanda aged 43, who is a fisherman.

She proposes to borrow Php 25,000 because she plans to get involved in raising pigs and fish, in meat vending and to continue her previous business. Specifically, the loan will be used to buy three pigs worth Php 9,500 and to retail them at a good price; additional fish net at a cost of Php 10,000 for her SKYLAB business (which comprises a section of fish cage made from net in which fish are easily caught); and bamboo and labor expenses amounting to Php 5,500. This loan will be a great help in making their dreams come true. 

Elenita hopes that God will give her a long life so she can help her children and future grandchildren to overcome the poverty line in their status in life.

loans.use: Purchase of fish net, bamboo, labor and three pigs

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary K. brews and sells local alcohol and she is requesting a loan to stock charcoal to sell. Mary is 40 years old and is widowed. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to start a charcoal store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock charcoal to sell

loans.name: Saret

texts.en: Mrs. Saret R., age 29, has been selling groceries in the Takhmao Market for 10 years. She has been married to Mr. Bros Ngov, age 35, since 1995. They live in a small village along National Road Number Two, about 12 kilometers from Phnom Penh City, and have three children, one son and two daughters. Two of the children attend school and the youngest one stays at home. Her husband sells pickle fruit. Saret is applying for her first loan of $500 to build a brick and concrete room under her wooden house.

loans.use: To build a brick and concrete room under her wooden house.

loans.name: Kampala One Group

texts.en:
Paulo K. is 45, married, and has six children between the ages of 3 and 19. He has a business making maize flour that he has run successfully for the past 3 years, and which earns him a monthly profit of around $115.

This will be Paulo’s third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans to increase his stock of maize, and has paid them back successfully. Paulo hopes for a loan to buy additional maize for his milling business.  
	
Paulo will share this loan with his loan group, Kampala One, which has 19 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable for the loan. In the picture Paulo, in the blue shirt, is center front.

loans.use: To increase his stock of maize for flour production

loans.name: Jovelyn

texts.en:
Jovelyn F. is from the village of Purok 8, Barangay Santiago, Iligan City. She is 29 years old. Jovelyn is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Jovelyn owns & operates a waste management service in which she hauls away junk and other waste material for local businesses and community members. Jovelyn has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Jovelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Jovelyn is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP to purchase additional waste and junk material to sell. This will be Jovelyn's 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional waste & junk material to sell

location.town: Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Honorata's Group

texts.en:
Honorata F., age 57, is married. She has 8 children and 9 grandchildren. Honorata has operated a chicken farm since 2005 and she just opened a grocery store. She works every day  from 6 a.m. until 6 p.m. She is able to make a monthly profit of around $260.

This will be Honorata’s 6th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used h previous loans to increase the size of her chicken farm, and repaid her loans successfully. She hopes to get a loan from Tujijenge Tanzania increase her stock even more and provide capital for her grocery shop.
	
Honorata will share this loan with her loan group, Green Tomalin, which has 16 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable for paying back their loans. In the picture, Honorata is at the centre front of the picture wearing a dark blue and light green dress.

loans.use: Stock for a grocery store

loans.name: Dara

texts.en:
Mr. Dara C., age 28, and his wife, Mrs. Preyvan Vanna, age 35, have been married for ten years and have seven children, five sons and two daughters. Three of the children live with their aunt in Phnom Penh, two children are in school, and another one is still too young for school. The family lives in a small village off of National Road Number Two, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia

Mr. Dara C. has been driving a Motor Remorque taxi (a motorbike with a trailer on the back) for more than eleven years. He carries goods and people from his village to Takhmao and Phnom Penh, and from Takhmao to his village. His wife is a garment factory worker. 

Dara has taken a previous loan from Kiva. He now is applying for another loan, again in the amount of $200, to repair his kitchen.

loans.use: To repair his kitchen

loans.name: Ronald

texts.en:
Ronald P. is from the village of Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 31 years old, married with two school-aged children. To make a living, Ronald owns and operates a service-based business venture in the services sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing transportation services to local community members. Ronald has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Ronald joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI. Ronald is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Ronald from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support members of his immediate family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel F. is from the village of Purok 8, Barangay Santiago, Iligan City. He is 35 years old. Joel is separated from spouse. To make a living, Joel provides mechanical services to local community members. Joel has been engaged in his business for over 4 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Joel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joel is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase the materials he needs to provide service. This will be Joel's first loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

location.town: Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda's desire to rise up from poverty and her dreams to have decent life motivated Yolanda to join ASHI, a Kiva field partner, in 2007. She hopes that God will always guide her whole family and give them more blessings to cope with their challenges and problems in life. She is always praying that her business will grow bigger, because it is one sources of their family income. And, also, she is asking for support from the good hands of our lenders and ASHI-Kiva for their hopes and dreams in life. They would  love to have a calm and relaxed house to live in. 

Yolanda M. is 52 years old and a good mother to her four children. She is married to Ruben, who is a 51-year-old fisherman, and also her partner in business. Because of her perseverance and hard work, and the income from her business, she provides a good education for her children so they can  finished studies until college. 

Yolanda is engaged in many businesses. She has a sari-sari (variety) store, she sells fish, she has a skylab business (a motorcycle with "outriggers" to carry passengers and cargo), and a fishing net that catches fish easily. 

For her fifth loan, she is asking for Php 23,000.00, which she will use Php 8,500.00 to buy fishing net, Php 7,000.00 for bamboo and rope, Php 1,000.00 for labor for their skylab business, and Php 6,500.00 to purchase of items for her sari-sari store. She is very innovative she enjoying seeing her life change. This loan will be a great help to her family as they strive to overcome poverty.

loans.use: To buy fishnet, bamboo and rope, to pay for labor, and to buy items for her store

loans.name: Dara

texts.en:
Mr. Dara C. has been a blacksmith for four years, while his wife stays at home to take care of their son. Dara doesn’t have enough materials to operate his business, so he is requesting his first loan of $550 to help purchase materials for his blacksmithing business.

Mr. Dara C., age 28, and his wife, Mrs. Sophea Thinh, age 25, have been married since 2007 and just have one young son. The family lives in the suburbs, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

loans.use: To purchase materials for a blacksmithing business

loans.name: Arabua

texts.en:
Arabua M. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and bundles of firewood in the market. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  

Arabua is 39 years old and married to a car driver.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for renting.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Solidad

texts.en:
Solidad C. is from the village of Purok 4, Barangay Santiago, Iligan City. She is 51 years old. Solidad is widowed. To make a living, Solidad provides waste-management services. The main source of income for her business comes from hauling plastics and other recyclables for local businesses and community members. Solidad has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month from these activities.

In 2009, Solidad joined HSPFI, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Solidad has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Solidad is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional plastics and other recyclables to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Solidad from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional plastics and other recyclables to sell

location.town: Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Kimhong

texts.en:
Mrs. Kimhong C. (shown in the picture), 32, is widow with two young sons. Besides her sons, she also has her mother living with her in a small village along the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Kimhong has been a silk weaver for 24 years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. She is requesting her first loan of $200 to purchase silk materials for her silk-weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her silk weaving business

loans.name: Chhoeut

texts.en:
Chhoeut L. is a 22-year-old resident of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. Chhoeut L. is married with three young children, who are students and dependent on her income. Her husband has been running a taxi service. 

To earn a living, Chhoeut L. gets small pieces of clothing from a garment factory and prepares them as sets for a fee. The cloth is used for turning into furnishings. Chhoeut L. dreams of owning a machine which will allow her to sew cloth for other furnishings to sell. That is why she has requested a loan of $500 to buy a sewing machine. This will help her to increase her income to make sure that her family attains a better standard of living.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Bagu

texts.en:
Bagu P. is currently in the business of selling bread and groundnut paste (a product of groundnut or simsim that has been ground or crushed into liquid). She is requesting a loan to purchase dried fish and tomatoes to sell.

Bagu is 40 years old and widowed. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family's settlement.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase dried fish and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Gey

texts.en: This is Gey N., a 31-year-old businesswoman who sells cosmetics and apparel. She is married to Donaban, 38, who is a businessman in the same industry. They have two children, one of whom is in high school while the other is in grade school. They live in Miramonte Park, Caloocan City. Gey sells cosmetics she gets from prominent direct-selling companies (Natasha, Avon, Fuller Life, etc.). The products include cosmetics, clothing and shoes. She has been doing this for two years now. Gey enjoys her business so much because she gets to know people from all walks of life in different parts of and even outside her community. She earns more than 18,000 Philippine pesos a month in net income. Being a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) credit cooperative has helped her business grow. She is now on her third loan. She applied for a loan in the amount of P8,000 as additional capital for her business. She will purchase cosmetics from her suppliers in advance to take advantage of rebates. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social-development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Melinda

texts.en:
Melinda O. is from the village of Calao West. She is 41 years old and married with 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Melinda owns and operates a tailoring business, providing general alteration and tailoring services to the local community. Melinda has been engaged in her business for many years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Melinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melinda is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials to expand her business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Melinda from ASKI.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics & materials

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en:
Mrs. Chantha K., age 49 (pictured) and her husband, Mr. Ngoun, age 46, have been married since 1979 and have 6 children - 3 sons and 3 daughters. One of the children is married and lives outside the family home, two attend school whilst the other children work in a garment factory. The family lives along National Road Number five about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Chantha operates a farm, growing rice. Her husband is a fisherman and also assists his wife on the farm. Chantha doesn’t have enough capital to maintain her rice farm; therefore she is requesting a loan of $700 to pay for plowing fees and to purchase fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.use: to pay for plowing, fertilizer and pesticide for rice farm

loans.name: Nuru

texts.en:
Nuru L. is a 29 year old widow with 4 children who all attend school. Nuru sells tea and local sudanese bread in a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase more powdered milk and tea to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bigger restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to purchase more powdered milk and tea to sell

loans.name: Marieta

texts.en:
From the striking and rich province of Rizal, Marieta C., one of the members of field partner ASHI-KIVA, has been engaged in buying and selling “ULING” (charcoal used for cooking instead of using gas stoves) for almost one year which gives her a reasonable income. For her fourth loan, she is seeking Php 15,000 specifically for the purchase of charcoal amounting to Php 7,000. Marieta will also get involved in buying and selling silver with loan funds of Php 6,000 and Vital C (vitamins) worth Php 2,000 because of her plan for a broader business so she can now step-by-step pursue her family's dreams.

She is married to her loving husband, Eugcuio C. aged 43, who is a soldier. They are happily living in the village of Kaytome Gulod on the island of Binangonan, Rizal, Philippines. She is blessed with three children; Marcel and Jenry are both soldiers and Donna Mae is still studying at college. The couple are so happy to see that their children also value good manners and correct conduct in the community.

She has always dreamt that her older children will be safe because of their work. Also she hopes that her youngest will finish her college degree and earn a good living in the future.

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal, silver and Vital C (vitamins) for sale

loans.name: Sun

texts.en: Sun M. is a 57-year-old woman who is the widowed mother of four children. Two of her children are married and currently live without a family home, while the other two are single. They all work at different jobs and provide their little income to meet what the family needs. Sun M. sells vegetables in the local busy market. In the past, she hired a taxi at a high cost to take her vegetables to the market and right now she is hoping to eliminate these expenses by using her first loan to buy a used motorcycle to use as transportation.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle to transport vegetables to market

loans.name: Busena

texts.en:
Busena C. is currently in the business of selling sodas and ice cream and is requesting a loan to purchase a fridge for cooling the sodas and ice cream.  Busena is 21 years old and is married with a husband who is a businessman. She has three children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase a fridge for cooling sodas and ice cream for sale

loans.name: Eustaquia

texts.en:
Eustaquia S. is 58 years old, married to Orlando who is a fisherman with an average income of Php 160.00 per day. The couple have four children, the eldest son is 34 years old and the youngest is 13 years old. 

Eustaquia and Orlando have been engaged in backyard hog raising (raising of pigs) for one year and have been a member of ASHI for almost one year. Their business has been the biggest support for their day-to-day needs especially their children's schooling. Through her determination and by being a good mother, Eustaquia provides for the needs of her children with the help of her business because her husband's income as a fisherman could not afford their children's education. This is why Estaquia is engaged in this business which also supports her four children's dreams.

They dream that someday their business will grow and that they can have a stable hog farming business in the future and a good life. She is proposing to borrow a loan amounting to Php 20,000.00 for additional capital in their hog raising business to prolong their fight against and rise up from poverty. Eustaquia will use the loan for the purchase of five piglets worth Php 7,500.00, five canvas sacks of feed amounting to Php 5,500.00, five sacks of binlid (food for pigs) and vitamins at a cost of Php 7,000.00, for the expansion of her business in order to sustain her family in a steady way of living. She hopes to see herself enjoying the profits of her business and to have a good life.

loans.use: To buy five piglets, sacks of feed and of binlid (food for pigs), and vitamins

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora J. is currently in the business of selling fresh fruit in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase fresh vegetables and more fruit to sell.  Nora is 20 years old and is married with a husband who is a potter. She has two children who do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to set up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase fresh vegetables and fruit to sell.

loans.name: 5622 Tuzamuranetwese Group

texts.en:
Rachel is 49 years old and married with seven children who are between the ages of 16 and 26. She lives in Gisenyi, a city at the border of Rwanda near the Democratic Republic of Congo. It is a three-hour drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. Rachel is the leader of her group and her business sells drinks and refreshments to the local community. Rachel is a hard worker and her business is open from 7 in the morning to 10 in the evening every day of the week.

Rachel is requesting a loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders in order to purchase more supplies and beverages to sell. She has seven years of experience in this business and she employs one person from her community as a helper. Rachel plans to save any additional profits, so she can continue to pay school fees for her many children. She thanks Kiva lenders and VFC for their support.

loans.use: Purchase more supplies and beverages to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Perina

texts.en:
Perina A. is currently in the business of selling beer and charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  She is 32 years old and is married with a husband who is a soldier. She has one child who goes to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to set up a house for renting.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Pork

texts.en: Pork P. is 33 years old and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She raises animals and grows rice to earn approximately US$1 profit every day. Her husband is a house dealer and makes US$5 per day. This couple has two young children. Pork P. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to make a new investment in order to raise her standard of living. She will use this loan to invest in a fruit stand business.

loans.use: To invest in a fruit stand.

loans.name: Cresenciana

texts.en:
Cresenciana is a 62-year-old woman, widowed and the mother of four children, none of whom have finished schooling because of poverty, three are at high school level and one is only at elementary level. She lives on the island of Buhangin, Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines.

With her belief and faith to get out of poverty, in 2008 she decided to join ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines. During her previous loans, she carefully invested in her sari-sari store business (a small retail store selling different goods) which gives her a reasonable income. Now on her third loan, she proposes to borrow the amount of Php 15,000 pesos as additional capital, again for her sari-sari store. Specifically, the amount will be used to purchase six sacks of rice worth Php 8,400.00, 50 kilos of sugar at Php 2,100.00, 50 bottles of cooking oil at Php 1,000.00, 50 packs of cigarettes at Php 1,300.00, and 50 liters of gasoline at Php 2,000.00 with the remaining Php 200.00 for travel fares. 

She hopes that her business will expand so that they will have savings for future use and dreams of having a successful general store, and also of helping her family to have a good life and to break the cycle of poverty.

loans.use: To buy sacks of rice, sugar, cooking oil, cigarettes and gasoline and to pay for travel fares.

loans.name: Par

texts.en: Par S., 52, is married with two young children living at home in the Takeo province. She works in a grocery store, typically making US$8 each day. Her husband has a business renting out musical equipment. Her husband, Nom Kim, typically makes about US$2 each day. Par S. would like a loan of US$1,000 to purchase more musical equipment.

loans.use: To purchase more musical equipment.

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en:
Nelson A. is from the village of Purok Pisces, Barangay Suarez, Iligan City. He is 59 years old. Nelson is married. To make a living, Nelson owns & operates a business repacking and selling health & medicinal products in the local community. Nelson has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nelson joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nelson has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Nelson is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Nelson from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth R. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste and charcoal and is requesting a loan to stock more groundnuts for making paste to sell.  Elizabeth is 22 years old and is married to a soldier. She has five children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more groundnuts for making paste to sell

loans.name: Un

texts.en: Un K. is a 32-year-old woman with insufficient capital who lives in the rural area of Phnom Penh city. Un K. produces and sells types of desserts to her villagers or other people who cross the street. Un K.’s husband, who is a motorbike taxi driver, also contributes to the family income. Un K.’s husband wants to replace his existing taxi because it is so small that it can only carry a few passengers and he cannot make much income. Because of that, Un K. would like to ask for a loan to allow her husband to buy a new taxi that is larger than the old one.

loans.use: To buy a new taxi

loans.name: Am

texts.en: Am S., 31, is married and lives with his wife in the Takeo province. He is a moto-taxi driver, typically making US$7 each day. His wife works in a grocery store, making approximately US$3 per day. This couple has four young children, two of whom are students and two are too young to attend school. Am S. is asking for a loan of US$1,000 to purchase a trailer that he can attach to his motorbike to transport more passengers. This will allow him to make more money.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer.

loans.name: Kibimbiri Group B, Kihihi

texts.en:
K. Kenneth is 53 years old and the leader of his lending group in Kihihi. He is married with six children aged 13 - 28 years old and he takes care of three other children and one orphan.

Kenneth has been a trader dealing in the buying and selling of fish from Kihihi town council for 15 years and he is happy that, at the moment, he is able to make 100,000/= as profits a week.

Most of Kenneth’s customers are daily customers, so he is sure of his daily sales and what to buy from the suppliers so that the fish do not go bad from non-sales.

He needs to expand his business so that he can win more customers and be able to build a permanent house for his family. He needs a loan to inject it in his fish business which will increase his stock, giving him more profits. Kenneth is such a trustworthy and welcoming man, and this has won him much.

loans.use: Buying more fish for resale.

loans.name: Shireen

texts.en:
Shireen is a 27 year-old single woman who lives in Nablus, a city in Palestine. Shireen has a beauty shop where she sells makeup, cosmetics, perfumes, creams and accessories.

She requested a loan of 3,000 US dollars from Ryada in order to purchase merchandise for her business.  Shireen will be able to grow her business and provide a better standard of living for her family.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her business

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Kim S., 28, is married with three young children living at home in Takeo province. She and her husband work making and selling hammocks at the local market to earn approximately US $7 of profit every day.

Kim S. would like to take out a loan of US $700 to buy mosquito nets, pillows and mats to sell at the market with the hammocks.

loans.use: Buy mosquito nets, pillows and mats.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn D.'s main source of income comes from raising pigs for sale. She is 30 years old, married and has four school-age children. They are from the village of Purok 4, Barangay Santiago, Iligan City. Jocelyn has been in her business for over four years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2009, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock to raise and sell in the future. At Jocelyn's discretion, her loan amount has been lowered down. This will be her second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to supplement the income of her family.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

location.town: Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Diogene

texts.en:
Diogene is 42 years old and is married with five children between 3 and 12 years old. Diogene lives in the Kicukiro, a region of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.  Here, Diogene owns a small kiosk selling a variety of drinks including milk and soda. This is his tenth successful year in business! He employs two people from his community and the hours of his business require that he works from 6 a.m. until late in the evening every day except Sunday.

Diogene is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. These funds will be used to purchase a wider variety of drinks and supplies for sale. Through this expansion, he hopes to attract more customers and sell more products.  As his sales increase, Diogene hopes that his life will change progressively as he will be able to make a bit more money through his efforts. This will allow him to reinvest a portion of profits in his business, continue to pay school fees for his children and set aside some savings for their future.

loans.use: To buy more soft drinks and supplies

loans.name: Phin

texts.en:
Phin S., 44, is married and lives with her son in Takeo province. To earn a living, she has been making and selling handicraft products at the local market. She earns approximately US $2 of profit every day. Her husband is a farm worker and makes less than US $1 per day. Phin S.’s son is a taxi driver who is able to make about US $5 of profit a day. 
Phin S. would like to take out a loan of US $1000 to purchase a motorbike to transport her craft products to the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport crafts to market

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen M. is currently in the business of selling ice cream in the market and is requesting a loan to stock sugar and milk to make ice cream to sell. Hellen is 30 years old and married to a policeman. She has six children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase a fridge.

About BRAC: BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock sugar and milk to make ice cream to sell

loans.name: Chil

texts.en: Chil C. is 43 years old and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She grows rice and works as a garment factory worker in the village. On average, she is able to make about US $3 of profit every day. Her husband is a moto-taxi driver earning US $7 per day. Chil C. is asking for a loan of US $1000 which her husband needs to replace an old and unreliable motorbike.

loans.use: To replace an old moto

loans.name: Efren

texts.en:
Efren T. runs a sari-sari (variety retail store). He is 54 years old, married and has seven grown-up children. He is from the village of Purok 4, Barangay Santiago, Iligan City. Efren has been in his business for over four years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2009, Efren joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. Efren has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Efren is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be his second loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue to supplement the income of his family.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Kibimbiri Group A, Kihihi

texts.en: T. Robert is very socialable and friendly. He is 37 years old and married with five children aged 12, 8, 6, 4, and 6 months. All his children are in school except for the baby that is still at home.  Robert has had a retail shop in the Kazinga neighbourhood for 8 years and he is able to make 65,000/=  profit a week from his sales. Robert says that he has many customers though some of them are debtors and these give him a headache. His dream is to ensure that he has a large variety of items in his shop for expansion, growth and saving for a family farm. Robert needs a loan to help buy more shop supplies of different types in stock.

loans.use: Restocking his retail shop with more goods.

loans.name: Berlie

texts.en: Berlie T. has a strong faith and is devoted for her dreams. She is a 34-year-old, a mother who cares of two children, both are students. Her husband, Jojit, is a fisherman. To lend a hand supporting the family Berlie has engaged in the fishing business, which is a common business on the island. She has applied for this loan in order to buy a variety of raw materials for her business, such as nets, rope, rolls of bamboo, bamboo sticks, and payment for labors, etc. In the future Berlie’s hopes to create a small stall in the market from which they can take orders of fish for consumers. She also wants to be able to save for her children's education to finish their degrees and find better jobs. She also desires to have a comfortable house for living and a happy family to live with. She would also like to have a successful business to help other people in their community.
