loans.use: To buy materials such as nets rope, rolls of bamboo, bamboo sticks and payment for labor,etc.

loans.name: Glenda

texts.en:
Glenda L. is from the village of Purok 4, Barangay Santiago, Iligan City. She is 33 years old. Glenda is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Glenda owns & operates a business venture in the services sector providing waste management services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from hauling plastics & other recyclables for local businesses and community members. Glenda has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Glenda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Glenda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Glenda is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional scrap metal to sell. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Glenda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase scrap metal to sell

location.town: Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
Riza R., 41, was born on February 14, 1968.  She is married to Antonio R. and both are blessed with two children. Born in the province of Masbate, a province just South of Manilas, he now lives in Dasmarinas, Cavite together with her family.

Riza has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than two years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow  seven times in the CCT’s Cooperative.  The reason why she was consistent in paying her loans was because she used all most all the money she loaned to buy and sell various personal products and office supplies to her clients.

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 18,000 loan. This amount will be mostly used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying additional stock and as payment for the monthly amortization of their motorized tricycle.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that when the time comes, they will have the resources to send their children to college. 


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: additional capital for buying and reselling personal products and office supplies

loans.name: Sorra

texts.en: Mrs. Sorra S. is a villager in Tralach village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 2-hectar field of land to cultivate rice. In this plantation, she faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed and fertilizers to support the rice field. Her husband, Mr. Huong Rathana, is a motorbike taxi driver. Mrs. Sorra S. is 27 years old and the mother of a child who is just three years old. Her husband and a child are presented in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizers to strengthen the rice field.

loans.name: Tameem

texts.en: Tameem runs a small chicken farm. He raises some for meat and others to sell their eggs. With the earnings from his small business, he is able to supplement his family’s income. He is 29 years old, single and lives with his parents. Tameem wants to invest in more chicks and feed and that is why he would like to borrow $3000 US. He says, "Thank you!"

loans.use: To invest in more chicks and feed

loans.name: Kitookye Society, Kihihi Group

texts.en: T. Justus is a hardworking and friendly man from Kitookye with a business selling produce and being a farmer. He is 49 years old and married with four children, ages 12, 7, 6 and 11 months. He is able to make 80,000/= profit every week and this helps run his home. Some customers buy his produce on credit, which is not good for business, but he has no choice since other traders do the same. He hopes to continue selling quality produce so that he can develop further and educate all his children. Justus needs a loan for business expansion so that he can buy and sell more produce.

loans.use: To buy more produce to sell

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet C. runs a general store selling food products in her community. She is 38 years old, married and has four school-age children. They are from the village of Paitan, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. Juliet has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2006, Juliet joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Juliet has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. Juliet is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her fifth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to pay for the tuition fees of her children.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Obou

texts.en:
Obou S., currently in the business of selling beer at home, is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell. Obou, who is 41 years old and married to a peasant, has seven children, all attending school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to establish a bar in the nearby market.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: C4352 Berwa Group

texts.en:
Vincent is 49 years old, married with 3 children aged between 10 and 15 years of age. He also takes care of 1 dependent from another family who is 11 years old. Vincent is the president of a group called “Berwa”. This group operates a sewing business in Kimironko which is in Kigali, Rwanda's capital city. Berwa employs 9 people and this is its 3rd successful year in operation. The members of Berwa start their work day at 7 AM and work to 8 PM every day except Sunday.

This group is requesting its first loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders in order to purchase additional sewing machines to increase their capacity. With this loan, Berwa will sew other attractive clothing styles for sale as well as additional sizes and colors. Through the use of this loan, this group hopes to attract more customers to its business and hopefully earn more profit in the process. Any additional funds earned will go to support their families and loved ones.

loans.use: Sewing machines

loans.name: Yong

texts.en:
Mr. Yong S., 50, a resident of Tralach village in Takeo Province, is a farmer who owns a plot of land upon which he cultivates rice. Because his field is infertile and he does not yet have rice seed, he is requesting a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizers, and pesticides for his farm.

His wife, Mrs. Suong Siem, is a grocer, and they have four children, two of whom stay at home to do housework while the others are attending the local school. His wife is shown in the picture with him.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizers, and pesticides.

loans.name: Venus

texts.en:
Still dreaming of rising up from poverty, Venus G., 49, is married to Ulizalde, a hog fattener. They have three children, two of whom are college graduates, while the youngest is still studying in college. To continue to support his education, she is hoping to expand her sari-sari store (a small retail store), which she has been operating for 17 years. While the business is just sufficient to support their daily needs, family income is limited.

A loan to expand the store will allow Venus to gain more profit and better serve her customers. The family dreams of adding a second floor to their house, adding capital to the business and saving for future use.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of goods including sacks of rice, gallons of mineral water, sacks of charcoal, and cooking oil for her store

loans.name: Ny

texts.en: Mrs. Ny H. lives in Prey Mean village in Takeo province. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Siem Moeun, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Although this couple works hard, they still earn little income to support their family. Thus, Mrs. Ny H. decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets, pig food, and fertilizers, and she would use the rest of money to buy some food to make soup to sell. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions with this loan. She is 45 years old and the mother of six children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy more piglets, pig food, fertilizer, and to buy ingredients to make soup to sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity A. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and dried fish and is requesting a loan to stock more fish to sell. Charity is 30 years old and is married with a husband who is a peasant. She has 7 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a charcoal store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Kanoni Tweyambe B, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
Henry T. is the leader of his group in Kihihi. He is a married man with 6 children aged 10 to 20 years old.  He is a business man who has been involved in agriculture for 10 years and is affected by the limited land available which limits the expansion of his business. In his farming business, he is also affected by limited labor.  Nevertheless, he is able to make 80,000 UGX in profits from his produce sales.

Henry has a tea plantation in addition to the banana plantations and he would like to expand further, buy more land, and educate his children. He needs a loan to be able to renovate his tea plantation so as to increase his income. Henry is really a social and hard working man who strives for success.

loans.use: To renovate his tea plantation for increased income.

loans.name: Consesa

texts.en:
Consesa C. is from the village of Baritao Manaog, Pangasinan. She is 45 years old. Consesa is married and has 4 school-aged children.

To make a living, Consesa owns and operates a business venture in the services sector providing recycling services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the business primarily earns income from hauling junk and other waste material for local businesses and community members. Consesa has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Consesa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Consesa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional waste and junk material to sell. Consesa is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional waste and junk material to sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Consesa from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional waste and junk material to sell

loans.name: Uk

texts.en:
Mrs. Uk S., 26 years old, is a young mother blessed with a young child who is not enrolled in school. 

Since 2006, Uk S. has been a tailor for a garment factory and earns a favorable salary of $90 a month. Another source of family income comes from her husband’s work as a blacksmith. Uk S.’s husband has been very busy because he has many customers, but he is still lacking some equipment to perform his services. Because of his needs, Uk S. is requesting a loan for her husband to buy a generator which will supply electricity to his business. 

Note: Uk S. was not available, so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To buy a generator

loans.name: Olaide

texts.en:
Olaide sells hair extensions and hair cream at retail prices in her shop. She is a hair stylist, and she sells hair materials to make a living. She is happy because the high season is here, and she hopes to make more sales during this season.

She is 43 years old and married with 4 children. Her children are doing well in school.

Olaide is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She hopes for a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more hair extensions and hair cream to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and hair cream to sell

loans.name: Jeremias

texts.en:
Jeremias D. is from the village of Purok 4, Barangay Santiago, Iligan City. He is 54 years old. Jeremias is married. To make a living, Jeremias provides waste-management services. The main source of income for the business comes from hauling plastics and other recyclables for local businesses and community members. Jeremias has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month from these activities.

In 2009, Jeremias joined HSPFI, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jeremias has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Jeremias is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional plastics and other recyclables to sell. It is Jeremias' discretion to lower his loan amount. This will be the second loan taken out by Jeremias from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional plastics and other recyclables to sell

location.town: Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Islam

texts.en:
Shoe-making is a trade that requires much hard work and dedication because one needs to have a vast amount of experience to make shoes in all types, styles and sizes for both genders. 

In the city of Gaza, Islam makes shoes for a living. He needs this loan to purchase raw materials used in the manufacture of shoes.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials used in the manufacture of shoes

loans.name: Tipayoa

texts.en:
Tipayoa A. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol and is requesting a loan to stock crates of beer to sell. Tipayoa is 38 years old and widowed. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Percita

texts.en:
Percita G. is 44 years old, married, and has an only child, Mark Anthony, 24 years old, a criminology graduate. They live in Bombong in a village of Talim Island located in Rizal Province, Philippines. In the year 2008, she decided to join ASHI ('rise up from poverty') KIVA's field partner, because of her eagerness to fight poverty and her aim to access more capital for her business so that she can supply the demand of her customers. On her third loan, she proposes the amount of Php 15,000 to use for the same businesses as before (fishing and her sari-sari store- a small retail shop).

This loan will be utilized for 10 pieces of bamboo, fingerlings, a fish net for her fish cage, rope, etc. amounting to Php 15,000. Her hopes and dreams are to expand their business to add more fish cages and also expand their sari-sari store to become a grocery store. She also wants good health and a good life for her family. These dreams give their life direction.

Percita appeals to the good hearts of Kiva lenders to support her loan and make their dreams real.

loans.use: pay for bamboo, fingerlings, fish net, etc.

loans.name: Chhom's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of twenty people and is located in Khnar Rung village in Takeo province. All the members will use the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Chhom M. is the village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice on. She is also a tailor. She is 43 years old, a widow with three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the other stays at home to do housework. Now Mrs. Chhom M. is requesting a loan to buy a cow to raise.

loans.use: to buy a cow to raise

loans.name: Kanoni Tweyambe Group, Kihihi

texts.en:
A. Annet is 28 years old and married with six children aged 11 – 1. She is a sociable and hard-working lady with a business in agriculture, a tea plantation in Kanoni cell for 7 years. Annet says that she is successful because of the location of her business and customer care, and she works hard to become well-off, to educate her children as well as expand further in business.

Annet needs a loan to be able to rehabilitate her tea plantation for expansion. She is the leader of her lending group in Kihihi.

loans.use: Rehabilitating her tea plantation for improved output

loans.name: Man

texts.en:
Man S., 26, is a grocer who owns a small shop along the road where she sells different kinds of foods to people who are nearby villagers or passers-by. She has a few employees who are her relatives to help her in selling foods and is typically earning approximately US$ 4 per day from her business.

Man S. is married with a lovely young child who is already enrolled in primary school, while her husband helps support his family by selling eggs at the market. Man S. wants to make additional income by investing in a new suitable business, but she doesn’t have money yet to start it. She is therefore looking for a loan from Kiva’s partner HKL to order imported kitchen supplies, such as pans, plates, and spoons. She will sell them retail at the market.

loans.use: To order cooking supplies such as pans, plates, spoons to sell

loans.name: Jerebell

texts.en:
Jerebell M. is a 34-year-old woman who dreams of having a long life in order to achieve her goal of meeting her “special someone”. Being single, Jerebell wishes that someday she will be able to meet a partner who will take care of her and will love her for the rest of her life. But for the meantime and while she is still searching she is preparing herself financially by growing her sari-sari store which means a small store that sells grocery items and other basic commodities.

The loans Jerebell has been accessing through ASHI help her business to grow and have enabled her to have savings and her own income to support the needs of her 80-year-old mother. Through loans she can obtain through ASHI, Jerebell envisions her business turning into a big grocery store wherein she can be a wholesaler to the small entrepreneurs like she is now.

loans.use: To purchase goods to increase her inventory

loans.name: Ismaeel

texts.en: Ismaeel is 31 years old. He is married and has three children to whom he wishes to give the best. He is very dynamic and cares deeply for his family. He has a small business where he sells different kinds of accessories for girls and women in the streets of the city of Gaza in Palestine. Today Ismaeel requesting a loan to buy more accessories to sell. He appreciates your kindness and generosity.

loans.use: Buy more accessories to sell

loans.name: Edmarie

texts.en:
Edmarie Roquillo is the struggling mother of four children. Since she has her own family and children to raise, she strives to have her own business and earn her own income to be able to provide the needs of her family and to bring joy and harmony into their home.

Edmarie believes that as a mother and a wife, she should have her own way of earning money and not depend on her husband’s income. During her first venture in a business and all throughout the years of maintaining it since 2003, ASHI has been her great source of financial capital. Despite the struggles she faces both in matters of the business and family, through credit from ASHI somehow her worries were always eased.

At this point in Edmarie’s growing business, she would like to request a much larger loan amount to supplement her working capital. Someday she wished her food retail business to grow and have the capacity to sell wholesale. But for the meantime, the proceeds she makes from her business are saved in preparation for the expenses required by the education of her four children who now range in age from four to 11 years old. She hopes that until their graduation from college, she will be able to give her support financially and morally.

loans.use: purchase a large volume of frozen goods and other kinds of easy-to-cook foods to sell

loans.name: Eyeda

texts.en:
Eyeda J. is currently in the business of importing clothes from Uganda and selling them in South Sudan and is requesting a loan to import bedsheets and pillows to sell. Eyeda is 24 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase a sewing machine and open a shop. BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: import bedsheets and pillows to sell

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic A. has been wishing for a business that would help her change the life that her family presently has. Her bad experience being poor and less educated, since her parents had nothing to support her studies at a higher level, flashes back every time she looks at her own children. Therefore, she is very much motivated to grow her business towards sustainability because the profit it generates provides her with the financial means needed to support her two children, four and six years old.

Although Marivic’s business is still small, she is willing to take each step slowly with the financial assistance she can access through ASHI and its partners until it grows big and becomes sustainable. Her loving husband who is a farmer supports her endeavor for the business and for their family.

loans.use: to finance her  cell phone pre-paid loading and softdrink sales business.

loans.name: Jymsie Amor

texts.en:
Jymsie Amor works hard running a business to be able to have her own income and to augment that of her husband, a laborer. This way she can give her only daughter a life that is better than what she has had since birth which has been nothing but poverty. Jymsie wants her daughter and the rest of the family to be healthy and happy. Through her profits she can buy foods that are nutritious.

By growing her business further, Jymsie wishes that someday she will also be able to support her child’s education until graduation from college. At that point, she will feel that she has fulfilled her role as a mother and a wife well with the help of the loans she requests through ASHI and its partners.

loans.use: buying ducklings and piglets to raise; also feed for the animals

loans.name: Bakry

texts.fr:
Monsieur Bakry S. a 37 ans, marié et père de trois enfants, il réside avec son épouse et leurs enfants au quartier Dioulasso de la ville de Kadiolo (dans la troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur S. fait la commercialisation de carburant notamment l’essence  et des articles de quincaillerie il y a environ sept ans. En plus de cette activité il cultive pendant l’hivernage 4 Ha de  maïs. 
Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. Son magasin se trouve au marché près de la route principale qui traverse  la ville de Kadiolo. 
Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida  de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt.
Il compte d’acheter avec ce prêt,  5 barriques  d’essence et 4 paquets d’articles de   quincaillerie  .
 Il s’approvisionne à Kadiolo ville auprès des grossistes et effectue sa vente journalièrement  dans la ville de Kadiolo en détail et au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce et payer les intérêts du prêt.
texts.en:
Bakry S. is 37 and lives with his wife and their three children in the Dioulasso neighborhood in the town of Kadiolo (in the third administrative region of Mali). He has sold fuel (mostly gasoline) and hardware for about seven years. Additionally, he raises corn on four hectares of land. He is appreciated by his customers for the quality of his products. His shop is in the market close to the main road through Kadiolo. Because he wanted to be able to meet the needs of his growing clientele, he decided to join Soro Yiriwaso (a microfinance organization). This is his first loan with Soro Yiriwaso. With this loan he plans to buy five barrels of gasoline and four cases of articles of hardware. He buys his merchandise from wholesalers in Kadiolo, and runs his retail business there every day, relying on a customer base of both men and women. With this loan he hopes to earn an average montly income of 35,000 FCFA, which he will mainly use to increase his capital and pay off the interest on the loan.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fuels and hardware.

loans.name: Larsie

texts.en: Larsie V. is from Guadiz St., Laoac, Pangasinan. She is 52 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Larsie owns and operates a business vending fruits and vegetables. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Larsie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used as additional capital for buying products to sell. Larsie is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will again be used to buy additional products to sell. This loan will her fifth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy additional products to sell

loans.name: Hermonisa

texts.en:
Hermonisa N. wishes that her business will become successful someday. Accessing loans through ASHI, a Kiva field partner in the Philippines, is one of the greatest opportunities which has enabled her to start reaching for her goal. Along with the business success she is dreaming about, graduation of her three children aged from a month old to five years old is also her greatest hope. The proceeds of her business give her money to support the immediate and basic needs of her family.

Despite hardship brought about by poverty to her and her family, Hermonisa remains strong and determined to change her family’s standard of living. The love and support she and her husband give to one another makes Hermonisa’s life meaningful. The desire to give her children a brighter tomorrow is the reason she keeps in her mind and heart not to surrender to poverty.

loans.use: To finance her rice buy and sell business

loans.name: Golda

texts.en:
Golda K. is currently in the business of selling fish and beer, and is requesting a loan to purchase fish and sell them in another nearby market. Golda is 29 years old and is married with a husband who is a driver. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase fish and sell them in another nearby market.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
53-year-old Gemma Santurdio is a woman who dedicated her life after marriage to her husband and five children. She worked very hard at several activities just to have her own income to augment that of her husband, a fisherman. Looking back on how she painfully started her life being a mother and a wife, she has learned that getting away from poverty was never easy. However, the determination she saw in her children to attain a higher level of education and finish college gives her courage and strength to combat poverty. With the help she has found in ASHI, KIVA's field partner in the Philippines, she is certain that she will change her family’s standard of living in the near future.

Gemma believes that in scrap and junk there is wealth. Aside from her desire to help her community maintain the cleanliness of its surroundings, Gemma also wants people to realize the value of maximizing things that they thought were useless in earning money. Therefore, she thought of putting up a business buying and selling scrap and junk. Empty plastic bottles, cans, used papers and metals are examples of things she buys from people and sells to a junk shop. For two years now, this business has been Gemma’s great financial provider. Someday, she really hopes to put up her own junk shop and to increase the proceeds from it.

loans.use: To finance buying and selling scrap or junk, such as metals and plastic bottles

loans.name: Girlie

texts.en:
Girlie S. would prefer to be a plain housewife and a full-time mother to her three children, who range in age from one to seven years old. However, she thinks that if the family depends on her husband alone to provide them money for buying basic things they need daily, the kind of life she will give to her children until they grow up will be the same. As a driver of a tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar that is used for transportation), Girlie's husband Bernabe earns only a small income.

Because of this, Girlie changed her plans last year, and she embraced the opportunity to get a loan through ASHI to invest in a business. After a year of realizing her happiness in running her own business and having her own income, she is requesting a much larger loan to further grow her business and profit; this will enable her to save money for the future education of her children until they graduate from college.

loans.use: To buy rice for a business buying and selling rice

loans.name: Bushura Tutungukye Group, Kihihi

texts.en:
M. Alice is 50 years old and married with two children, aged 20 and 17 years, and she takes care of two dependents.

Alice has had a retail shop in Bushura cell for 3 years. She is able to make 30,000/= profit a week. This can be mostly attributed to the availability of items in her shop, although defaulters are also many. Apart from the shop, Alice is also a farmer and she would like to become rich in the future and have a better standard of living.

Alice needs a loan to be able to restock her shop with more goods and to buy seeds and pesticides to improve and expand her plantations. Alice is the leader of her lending group in Kihihi and a very hardworking lady.

loans.use: Restock her shop with more goods, and buy seeds and pesticides for her farm

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
At age 67, Rosario D. still wants to maximize her potential and strength in managing a business. She was born poor and even now, she is used to working hard to earn money to support her own needs and those of her husband. Both are living alone now and are helping each other to survive despite their poverty.

Since a year ago, Rosario has been raising ducks in their wide backyard for a business. Once the ducks grow up, she sells them in the market. Sometimes people also come to her house to buy eggs and ducks. Aside from the profit Rosario earns from raising the ducks, she also feels happy to raise them the way she raised her own children who are now having own families.

Despite her age, Rosario is still hoping that she can change the standard of living of her family through her business. Therefore, she is now requesting a much larger loan to be able to raise more ducks and sell them when they grow up.

loans.use: To purchase more duckling for backyard poultry-raising business.

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en: Mohammad is a Palestinian man living in Tulkarem City. Currently he just lives with his wife, as all his children are married and have their own houses. Mohammad is working as a Muezzen/servant for the mosque (in Islam there are five prayers at various times during the day, from dawn until sunset, so there is a Muezzen who calls for the prayers each time using a loudspeaker so everyone can hear him and do their prayers). This is a government job through the Ministry of Awqaf (Islamic Religion). Mohammad's job is the only source of income for him. He requested $2,000 from FATEN to do some renovation to his house, as it is an old building and needs renovation, especially now that winter has started. Mohammad appears in the picture at the FATEN office. Mohammad is wearing one of the Palestinian traditional head covers.

loans.use: Renovations for his house

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe V. is 46 years old and a good mother to her three children, She is married to her compassionate spouse Arnulfo V., a farmer and tricycle driver. They currently live at an attractive place, Morong, Rizal. She is engaged in a farming business and also get involved in hog raising (raising of pigs).

Presently two of her children are studying in college and one is a nursery student. She hopes to finish the studies of children through the benefit of having loans from ASHI, KIVA's field partner. She believes that her business will help her family to rise up and fight against poverty, as well as provide for the educational needs of her 3 children and enable them to have a comfortable house to live in.

She plans to utilize this loan of Php 45,000 to expand her farming business and get involved in other businesses for supplementary profits. This loan will be used to buy fertilizer (Php 30,000.00), pigs (Php 8,000.00), and feed (Php 7,000.00). During her 10 years as a member of ASHI, Fe V. has shown very good performance, and she is being trusted by ASHI for the length of time she stayed. Having this loan will enable her to finally achieve her dreams in life: to have a winning business, the best in life, and a happy family as well. She is very thankful to ASHI for the continued support of her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, pigs, and feed for pigs

loans.name: Atieh

texts.en:
Atieh is was born in 1979. He is married and has 3 children who all live in Gaza City, Palestine.

Atieh owns a pastry shop where he sells all sorts of cakes and pastries. He always looks for ways to improve his business and therefore has been able to grow a good base of loyal customers. He opened the pastry shop because he enjoyed making and selling pastries and wanted to have an independent work life. In the future, he plans to expand and improve his work.

The loan he is asking for, USD 3000, is to purchase raw materials and thereby diversify his inventory of goods.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials for his bakery

loans.name: Eufemia

texts.en:
Eufemia L. is an old woman by age, but strong and healthy. She is capable of running her own business to earn money, which she uses to support her mother and her own family. Since 2008 she has been requesting loans through her membership in ASHI, KIVA's field partner in the Philippines. Thos loans have made her productive by growing a business. All throughout her membership, she has showed very good performance in repayment and attendance during weekly center meeting. She enjoys the camaraderie of her fellow members in ASHI as well as the input about managing a small business she learned from them.

With a much larger amount of business capital in addition to the knowledge she has learned from her fellow small entrepreneurs, Eufemia would be able to enhance the growth of her business, with the help of her husband and a 46-year-old child who is a laborer and lives with her. Therefore, at this point of her membership in ASHI, she is requesting a certain amount based on the need of her business and her capacity to pay back.

loans.use: To purchase groceries and other commodities to sell in her variety store

loans.name: Fredeswinda

texts.en:
Fredeswinda B. is from the village of baybay Bonifacio. She is 41 years old. Fredeswinda is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Fredeswinda owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling fish in the local communities. Fredeswinda has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 3,300 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Fredeswinda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fredeswinda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Fredeswinda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and for daily needs.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita S. is a hardworking grandmother, mother, and wife. She has no other wish for herself but to see her grandchildren happy and enjoying their lives out of the umbrella of poverty. Her three grandchildren, who range in age from eight to 12 years old, are her inspiration and reason to be productive. She feels responsible for them because her son has no stable source of income to support his family. Somehow she considers herself unlucky for the achievements of her only child whom she worked hard for.

However, having loving and sweet grandchildren, she has found the reason to live again and have a business. That is why she joined ASHI, KIVA's field partner in the Philippines--to be able to have access to credit that she will use as capital in starting a small business.

loans.use: To finance a rice production (rice planting) business

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa sells groceries, drinks and rechargeable phone cards at retail prices. With these combined businesses, she hopes to meet the basic needs of her family. She has been in this business for a long time.

Hawa is a Lift above Poverty Organization (LAPO) client. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. Hawa hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more groceries, and rechargeable phone cards to sell.

Hawa is 40 years old and is married with four children. She lives in Lagos state, Nigeria. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and rechargeable phone cards to sell

loans.name: Laron

texts.en:
Laron P., 30, is a resident of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. She has been married for two years and has given birth to a young child. Her husband is a photographer. She currently lives with her mother who helps her in caring for her child and in doing housework as well. Her mother is shown in the photo.

Laron P. works sewing clothes in a factory and started early in 2007. The family finds it hard traveling to work or anywhere else and also pays a lot of money for taxis because they have no vehicle for their transportation needs. That is why Laron P. has decided to seek a loan to buy a motorcycle to make her family's transportation easier.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle for her family's transportation needs

loans.name: Soeung

texts.en:
Soeung T., 49, is married with three children living at home in Takeo province. Two of the children are students and one is a construction worker.

Since 2000, Soeung T. has been working as a scarf weaver earning approximately US$5 of profit per day. Her husband is a mechanic, fixing motorbikes and bicycles in the village. On average, he is able to make US$4 of profit each day. 

Soeung T. is asking for a loan of US$1,200 to purchase mechanic’s tools for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase mechanic's tools for her husband

loans.name: Souleymane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Souleymane S. a 34 ans et marié, il vit  dans une famille monogame avec sa femme et ses  6 enfants à Nimbougou dans la commune rurale de Loulouni, préfecture de Kadiolo, 3eme région administrative de la république du Mali.  
Il fait le commerce d’articles  divers de boutique et de céréales depuis  maintenant 15 ans. 
Expérimenté en raison des années dans le commerce, il le mène avec une grande réussite.
Il est à sa troisième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Les deux  prêts passés se sont  bien dénoués. 
Il compte acheter avec son prêt, 5 paquets d’articles divers de boutique et  2 tonnes de céréales (riz et maïs). Il s’approvisionne à Sikasso ville, à Zegoua et au marché de Loulouni les jours de foire.
Il vend au comptant et souvent à crédit, en gros et en détail, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Il envisage de réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 45.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour augmenter le fonds de commerce et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne car il ambitionne construire une maison à usage d’habitation à Sikasso.
texts.en:
Mr. Souleymane S. is 34 years old and married; he lives in a monogamous family with his wife and six children in Nimbougou in the rural community of Loulouni, Kadiolo prefecture, 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali.

For almost 15 years now he has been selling various grocery items and cereals. He is seasoned because of years in the business, and conducts it with great success. This is his third collaboration with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. The two previous loans were resolved well.

With this loan, he is hoping to buy 5 packs of various grocery items, and two tons of cereals (rice and corn). He sources his goods from Sikasso town, in Zegoua and at the Loulouni market on fair days.

He sells for cash and often at credit, in bulk or retail to customers made up of women and men.

He is planning to make an average monthly profit of 45,000 FCFA of which one part will be used to increase his working capital and the other will be placed in savings. He is aspiring to build a house to be used as a dwelling in Sikasso.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cereals

loans.name: Dielika

texts.fr:
Madame Dielika C. a 38 ans, marié et mère de cinq enfants, elle réside avec son épouse et leurs enfants au quartier Noumouso de la ville de Kadiolo (dans la troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Dielika C. fait la commercialisation de céréales (graines) il y a environ dix  ans. Elle jouie d’une grande affluence pour la qualité de ses produits et est très sollicitée dans la ville de Kadiolo et environ. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle collabore avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant deux ans.  Après trois  prêts tous remboursés sans difficulté, elle est à son  quatrième prêt pour augmenter son fonds de commerce afin d’acheter, 1 tonne de  céréales.
 Elle s’approvisionne dans les villages environnants de kadiolo. Les marchandises sont vendues à domicile journalièrement en détail, souvent à crédit et le jour de foire au marché de la ville de Kadiolo en gros et  au comptant  à une clientèle composée essentiellement de forains( venant de Sikasso, Ségou, Bamako).
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 37.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts du prêt.
texts.en:
Mme Dielika C. is 37, and lives with her husband and their five children in the Noumouso neighborhood of Kadiolo, a town in the third administrative region of Mali. She has been selling grain for about 10 years. Because of the quality of her produce, she has a large customer base and is well regarded in Kadiolo and the surrounding area. To meet the needs of her growing clientele, she has worked with Soro Yiriwaso (a microfinance institution) for two years. She has repaid three loans with no problems, and is asking for a fourth to increase her capital and buy one tonne of grains from villages near Kadiolo. She sells her merchandise every day at retail from her home, frequently giving credit. On the days of the fairs in the Kadiolo market, she sells her merchandise at wholesale prices, mostly to stallholders who come from Sikasso, Ségou and Bamako. With this loan, she believes she can generate a monthly net income of 37,000 FCFA, which she will use to enlarge her working capital, to help pay family expenses, and to pay interest on her loan.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy grains.

loans.name: Marjorie

texts.en:
Marjorie S. lives in the village of Paitan, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 35 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Marjorie sells a variety of different products from her community store. She has been engaged in this business for more than two years and earns approximately 3800 PHP a month from her work.

In 2006, Marjorie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid four previous loans from ASKI, and has applied for a new loan of 7,000 PHP which she will use to buy more inventory and expand her store. She plans to use the income generated by this loan to support her family. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell and expand her store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anchata

texts.fr:
Madame Anchata M. a 32 ans, marié et mère de quatre enfants, elle réside avec son époux et leurs enfants au quartier Noumouso de la ville de Kadiolo (dans la troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Anchata M. fait la commercialisation du beurre de karité et de tubercules  il y a environ quatre ans. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de son beurre de karité.
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de collaborer  avec  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant  2 ans. 
Après  trois prêts tous remboursés correctement, elle sollicite son quatrième prêt pour augmenter son fonds de commerce afin d’acheter,  6 sacs de 100kg de noix de karité et 2 sacs de 100kg de patates.
 Elle s’approvisionne à Kadiolo ville les jours de foire et souvent dans les villages environnants. Ces noix sont d’abord transformées en beurre de  karité avant d’être revendues.  
Ses produits sont vendus  à domicile  et au marché de la ville de Kadiolo les jours de foire, en gros, au comptant à une clientèle composée essentiellement de forains (Sikassois).
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 19.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, payer les intérêts de son prêt et épargner le reste.
texts.en:
Mrs. Anchata M. is 32 years old, married and the mother of four children. She lives with her husband and their children in the Noumouso district of the town of Kadiolo (in the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Anchata M. has been selling shea butter and tubers for around four years. She is in great demand from her customers because of the quality of her shea butter. In order to satisfy increasing customer demand, she decided to collaborate with the microfinance company, Soro Yiriwaso, two years ago. Having repaid three loans punctually, she is asking for a fourth loan to increase her working capital in order to buy six 100kg bags of shea nuts and two 100kg bags of potatoes. She stocks up in the town of Kadiolo on fair days and often in the surrounding villages. The nuts are firstly made into shea butter before being sold on. Her products are sold wholesale for cash at home and at the market in Kadiolo on fair days to customers who are mainly fairground workers (Sikassois). With this loan she plans to make an average monthly profit of 19,000 FCFA which will be used principally to increase her working capital and pay the interest on her loan; she will save anything that is left.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of shea nuts

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 27 years old and is married without children. He and his wife live in Musanze, a region of Ruhengeri, in the Northern Province of Rwanda.

Samuel is proud to have been a self-employed businessman for five successful years. He works from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day except Sunday. His wife works in the business of animal husbandry and earns a small income as well.

Samuel is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. He plans to use the loan to buy more bags and luggage for sale. Any additional profits will be reinvested in his business in order to improve his financial stability. He also hopes to improve the well being of his extended family and build a secure future for them in the process.

loans.use: To buy more bags and luggage for sale

loans.name: Chann

texts.en: Chann P., 38, makes a living cooking specialized dishes that are served at weddings in his home provence of Takeo. He typically makes about $3 per day, and that income is supplemented by his wife, who makes $2 a day from farming. The couple has five school-aged children. Chann P. has applied for a loan for $1,200 to expand his business. When someone hires him to prepare food for a wedding, these funds will help him provide the meal quickly and efficiently.

loans.use: to expand a business providing wedding banquets

loans.name: Mrs. Choeun Thinh Village Bank Group

texts.en: This group is made up of 20 people who live in the village of S. in Takeo province. Mrs. Choeun T. has been chosen to lead the group, whose members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Choeun is a farmer who owns a one-hectare field on which she cultivates rice. Her main problem is low soil fertility, and she will use her portion of the loan to buy seeds and fertilizer. Her husband, Mr. Doeuk Voeun, is a fisherman. Mrs. Choeun T. is 37 years old and has two children, one of whom is old enough to attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer for her rice farm

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 32 years old and is married with six children between 5 and 12 years old. Daniel and his family live in Burera, a region of Ruhengeli situated in the northern province of Rwanda.  From here to Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda, it takes 2 hours drive.

Daniel has been a successful entrepreneur in the retail business for the past nine years and he employs two people from his community in his general store. Their hours of work are from 6:30 a.m. to 7 p.m. every weekday.

Daniel is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. With these funds, he plans to purchase more items to add to his offerings such as sugar, salt, soap, buckets, Vaseline, mineral water etc.

Additional products tend to attract more customers and boost his sales, especially near Christmas time. If his plans succeed, he will reinvest a portion of his revenues in his business and be able to save enough in order to pay school fees for his six children and better provide for his family’s future.

loans.use: To purchase more goods for his store

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet makes a living selling hair extensions and hair cream to her customers. She is also a stylist who is popular for the creative work she does on people's hair. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to meet the many demands of her customers. Juliet is married, has five children and  is 40 years old. She has applied for a loan for NGN 70,000 to buy more hair extensions and hair cream to sell. She extends her sincerest thanks to all  Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more hair extensions and cream to sell

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Kong S. is 52 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Takeo province. She and her daughter, who we see here, make a living by weaving scarves. On a typical day, they earn about $3 by working together. Mrs. S.'s husband is a farmer and makes $2 a day. She has applied for a loan for $1,200, which she will use to buy silk that she and her daughter will weave into scarves and sell at the local market.

loans.use: To buy silk to weave into scarves

loans.name: Mrs. Rorn Chea Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of fourteen people and they all live in Svay village in Takeo province.

Mrs. Rorn C. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. H. Kosal, is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which he cultivates rice.

Since the pigs are getting bigger and bigger, Mrs. Rorn C. decided to ask for a loan bU. more pig feed and fertilizer to support the rice field. She hopes to increase their income and improve the family’s standard of living with this loan.

Mrs. Rorn C. is 27 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the other is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more pig feed and fertilizer to support the rice field

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Chin

texts.en:
K. is 57 years of age and is the widowed mother of seven children. Four of her children are married and live independently and the remainder are single.

K. owns a restaurant located near the market, where she sells Chinese noodles and soft drinks. Most of her children also help her in the business when they are not working or studying.

K. wants to improve her business in order to achieve her goal of attracting more clients. She is asking for a loan to widen her restaurant and to buy more attractive equipment to decorate her shop.

loans.use: To widen her restaurant and to buy more attractive equipment to decorate her shop

loans.name: Thau

texts.en:
Thau T., 36, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She is a professional scarf weaver who is able to make about US$3 of profit each day while her husband is a farm worker who is able to make about US$2 per day. This couple has three school-aged children.

Thau T. is asking for a loan of US$1,000 to purchase a water pump for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump for her husband

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en:
Taiwo sells food spices and foodstuffs in her shop at retail prices and has been in this business for three years. She is a friendly woman and she uses her friendly skills to attract more customers to her shop.

Taiwo is 31 years old and is married with two children. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria.

Taiwo is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. Taiwo hopes for a loan of NGN 140,000 to purchase more food spices to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more food spices

loans.name: Artemia

texts.en:
Artemia has been a member of ASHI since 2003 and has an excellent performance. She is 62, married, and has two grandchildren who are now independent of her. They live at Morong, Rizal, Philippines. Her children already have their own living with their partners in life.

Facing the necessity of supporting the household and being self-motivated, Artemia started a small business of sewing RTW (ready to wear clothes). She started it with Php 5,000 and she has gotten results from the beginning because of the quality of her products, the reasonable prices, and the good attention she gives to the customers. She currently continues with the same business, which is located in her own house. Her main customers are her neighbors and people at the market.

Artemia will use this loan of PHP 40,000 to stock her business, like buying Tela (cotton) for curtains, jeans, shorts, blouses, and pajamas for a broader expansion of her business and to buy other products to keep her customers happy.

Artemia now feels very happy about her work and the service that ASHI and Kiva provide, offering her big opportunities to make her dreams come true. She is grateful to them for supporting people like her who want to work and get ahead. She hopes they continue this way for a long time and help many families and enterprising women.

loans.use: To purchase tela (cotton) for curtains, jeans, shorts, blouses, pajamas, etc.

loans.name: Navy

texts.en:
Navy S., 49, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province. To earn a living, she raises pigs and makes rice wine together with her husband and earns approximately US$5 of profit every day.

This couple has five children, four of whom are students and one is a local garment factory worker. Navy S. is asking for a loan of US$1,200 to purchase rice to resell.

loans.use: To buy rice to resell

loans.name: Allah Kan Dèmè Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Allah Kan Dèmè est composé de six  femmes dont une célibataire et cinq mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames et vivant  dans le quartier Hamdallaye de  la ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative de la république  du  Mali). Elles ont en moyenne 34 ans et 3 enfants. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de leurs activités commerciales et font le commerce d’articles divers.
Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt solidaire, elles sont à leur 2ème  prêt en vu de  diversifier et de rentabiliser leur activités. 
Ce prêt servira à acheter, 3 pièces de 30 mètres de bazin blanc, 10 pièces de pagnes wax,  35 habits pour enfants (des layettes, des robes, complet culottes, complet jupes), 20 complets de chaînes, boucles d’oreilles, bracelets et quelques bagues, 12 flacons de vernis  12 crayons d’antimoine, 250kg de riz et 500 kg de tubercules « fabourama ». 
Elles s’approvisionnent la plupart du temps au marché château de Ségou, avec les forains venant de Massigui et à  Niono. Leurs marchandises sont revendues au même marché château de Ségou, les pagnes wax en ambulant dans les quartiers d’Hamdallaye et le « fabourama » au marché de Médine. La vente se fait au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 27.835FCFA qui sera consacré au remboursement des prêts,  à la contribution aux charges familiales, à la participation aux évènements sociaux (baptêmes, mariages, circoncisions et funérailles),  à l’achat  de matériels constituant ainsi petit à petit le trousseau de mariage des jeunes filles et à la constitution d’épargne.
texts.en:
The Allah Kan Dèmè group comprises six women, one of whom is single and the other five married, - the majority in monogomous marriages - living in the Hamdallaye area of the town of Ségou (in the 4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are on average 34 years old with 3 children. They met each other through neighbours and through their businesses, and they sell a variety of products. Having repaid their first joint loan without any problem, they are now on their second loan with a view to diversifying and making their business profitable. This loan will be used to buy 3 pieces of 30-meter long white bazin, 10 wax-printed loincloths, 35 items of children's clothing (baby clothes, dresses, trouser suits, skirt suits), 20 sets of chains, earrings, bracelets and some rings, 12 bottles of varnish, 12 khol pencils, 250kg of rice and 500kg of "fabourama" tubers. Most of the time they get their supplies from the Château de Ségou market, from the fairworkers coming from Massigui, and at Niono. They sell their goods at the same Château de Ségou market, the wax-printed loincloths while walking through the Hamdallaye neighbourhoods and the "fabourama" at the market in Médine. The goods are sold for cash and on credit to both male and female customers. They are expecting to make an average monthly profit of 27,835 FCFA which will be used to repay loans, and also to contribute to household expenses and social events (baptisms, marriages, circumcisions and funerals), the purchase of items which will gradually make up young girls' marriage trousseaux as well as the building up of savings.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various products

loans.name: Mrs. Sok Heang Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of thirteen people, is located in Svay Village in Takeo province and all the members will use the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Sok H. is the village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Hean Pheap, is a fisherman. Aside from his fishing, he is also a construction worker. This couple does not have any children yet.

Although this couple tries to work hard, they still earn less income than needed to support the family living. Thus, Mrs. Sok H. decided to ask for a loan to buy two piglets to raise and pig feed.

loans.use: To buy two piglets and pig feed

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Balel Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Balel est composé  de cinq femmes, une veuve et quatre  mariées majoritairement dans des familles  polygames. Ayant  en moyenne 44 ans, 5 enfants, elles habitent  dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Ségou  (4ème Région administrative de  la république du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et sont toutes membres d’une  même association d’entre aide.  Elles font généralement  le commerce d’articles divers, la couture et l’embouche ovine. 
Elles sont à leur 5ème prêt solidaire, après avoir remboursés sans difficulté les quatre précédents. 
Ce nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 100 pastèques, des citrons et des oranges, 10 pièces de pagnes wax, 6 habits  en cotonnade « Faso danfani », 4 rouleaux de popeline de diverses couleurs, 6 paquets de files  pour la broderie à la main, 1 chargement en bois de chauffe bois, 7 sacs de henné et 5 moutons. 
Elles s’approvisionnent en pastèque à Boki Wèrè, en citrons et oranges aux vergers, en pagnes wax  et en habits en cotonnade à Bobo-Dioulasso (Burkina Faso), en popeline, files et  henné dans le  marché Château de Ségou, le bois est acheté  à Tona, les moutons sont achetés à Konodimini. La plupart de ces marchandises est vendu, au marché Château, à domicile, au comptant, en détail, en gros et à crédit,  à une  clientèle  qui se compose d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles  espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 41.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des prêts, l’achat de nourriture,  de savons, de fournitures scolaires et de médicaments. 
Leur ambition est avoir une concession et assurer l’éducation et la formation de leurs enfants.
texts.en:
The Balel group is made up of five women – one widow and four married – who mainly live in polygamous families. They are, on average, 44 years old, have an average of five children each, and live in the Hamdallaye quarter of Ségou town (the fourth largest administrative region in the Republic of Mali). They met through neighbours and are all members of the same mutual-aid association. They are generally involved in the sale of miscellaneous items, dressmaking, and in sheep fattening. They are on their fifth solidarity loan, and have successfully repaid their four previous ones. This new loan would be used to buy 100 watermelons, some lemons and oranges, 10 pieces of colourful fabric [pagne wax is a West African term for a highly decorative colourful material], 6 ‘Faso danfani’ cotton suits, 4 rolls of poplin in various colours, 6 packs of hand embroidery thread, one cartload of firewood, 7 bags of henna and 5 sheep. They source their watermelons from Boki Wèrè, their lemons and oranges from orchards, their colourful fabric and cotton suits from Bobo-Dioulasso (Burkina Faso), and their poplin, thread and henna from the Château de Ségou market. The women buy their firewood from Tona, and their sheep from Konodimini. The majority of their merchandise is sold both individually and in bulk at the Château market and through home sales. Cash and credit payments are received from a customer base made up of both men and women. They aim to make an average monthly profit of 41,000 FCFA which would be used to repay loans and to buy food, soap, school equipment and medicine. Their ambition is to have a house and to guarantee the education and training of their children.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of various items.

loans.name: Folashade

texts.en:
Folashade sells crates of drinks at retail prices to her customers at her stall. She has been in this business for a long time. She loves this business because it is highly competitive and she makes a lot of profits.

Folashade lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 38 years old and married with two children. Her children are in a private secondary school.

This is the high season for business and Folashade hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to expand her business with a loan of NGN 140,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes, 58 years old, comes from Morong, in the lovely province of Rizal, Philippines. She has been involved in her business for more than 10 years. She is married to Florante G., a farmer, and is a diligent and careful mother of four children.

Mercedes' husband's income is not enough to meet the needs of their family. In 2000, Mercedes got the idea of joining ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines. She was given hope and a way to have access to capital, so she started her sari-sari store (a small retail business selling different goods). The business went smoothly and brings them good income. Mercedes also got the idea to put up capital for a canteen eatery (preparation of ready-to-eat food) because of the demand.

Currently on her seventh loan, Mercedes proposes the amount of Php 35,000 as additional capital to purchase stock and more supplies for her consumers' demands. Stock includes items such as soft drinks, beer, drinks, meat, fish, vegetables, rice, Fundador, cooking oil, sugar, etc.

Mercedes has disciplined herself to use all of the borrowed capital from ASHI-KIVA for her business, to gain more profit and to use that profit to support daily expenses. She got involved in ASHI (10 years) for the dreams of her family, to send her children to school and to finish their studies with a degree. Actually, she has already completed half of her dreams because her children have their degrees but she didn’t stop dreaming for her grandchildren, to offer them the best education, as she provided for her children. The couple feels very happy with the loan that changed their lives to be better than before. Mercedes wishes all lenders all the best and good luck and will continue to support her family and the expanded business.

loans.use: purchase of stock and supplies

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Danaya comprend six femmes, deux veuves et quatre  mariées dans des grandes familles traditionnelles, elles ont  en moyenne 37 ans, 4 enfants et habitent le quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative  de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage, professionnel, d’amitié et font le commerce d’articles  divers, la teinture et la restauration.
Dans le souci rentabiliser et de diversifier leurs activités elles ont décidé d’adhérer au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 5ème prêt solidaire après avoir correctement remboursés les quatre précédents. 
Ce  prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 20 chargements de charrettes en  bois de chauffe, 10 sacs de riz et 35 tenues vestimentaires pour enfants. 
Elles s’approvisionnent en riz habituellement  au marché Château de Ségou, en  bois de chauffe auprès des exploitants  de Diakoro et de Kolonkolo et les habits  pour enfants au marché château. Les ingrédients pour la restauration le  riz, le haricot, les spaghettis, le poisson, la viande etc sont achetés au grand marché de Ségou. 
Elles effectuent leur vente en détail au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 43.250FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt, à la satisfaction des petits besoins familiaux et à la participation aux évènements sociaux (baptêmes, mariages, funérailles). 
Leur ambition est d’avoir  une concession à usage d’habitation propre à leurs enfants et à elles car le commun n’est pas une propriété en soi.
texts.en:
The Danaya group includes six women, two widowed and four are married in big traditional families. They are on average 37 years old with 4 kids and live in the Hamdallaye neighborhood in the town on Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali.) They know each other from around the neighborhood, through professional ties and friendship. They do business in a varied goods as well as cloth dyeing and food preparation. It's in the wish of making more profitable and diversifying their activities that they decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program. They are on their 5th group loan after correctly repaying the 4 proceeding ones.

This loan would be used to buy 20 cart loads of firewood, 10 bags of rice and 35 children's outfits. They usually stock up on rice at market in Château de Ségou, on wood from farmers in Diakoro and Kolonkolo and on kids clothing at Château market. The ingredients for the food preparations the rice, the beans, the noodles, the fish and meat are bought at the large market of Ségou.

They carry out their retail sales in cash and credit to both men and women. The plan to average a monthly income of 43.250FCFA which would be used to repay the loan, to see to the small needs of the families and be used to participate in social events (baptisms, marriages and funerals.) Their dream is to have claim to decent housing for them and their kids because the joint housing is not solely owned by them.

Translated from French by Colleen Creegan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of varried goods

loans.name: Fatimum

texts.en:
Fatimum sells drinks and frozen foods from her house. She is happy because she does not have to pay to rent a stall. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She has been in this business for 8 years.

Fatimum is 32 years old, married with 4 children. She lives in Badagry, Lagos State, Nigeria. Fatimum hopes for a loan in the amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more frozen foods and crates of drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks and frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Djiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djiguiya est composé de six femmes (deux veuves et quatre mariées) qui ont en moyenne 38 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des familles monogames dans  le quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Elles  font le commerce d’articles divers, la restauration et sont à leur 2ème prêt de groupe après avoir remboursé sans aucune difficulté le premier. 
Ce  prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter, 5 pièces de pagnes wax, 3 couvertures en laine, 3 couvre-lits, 65 habits pour enfants (des robes, complet- culottes, complet jupes et des layettes), des condiments alimentaires (150 bols de poudre de feuilles de baobab, 50 bols de piment, 1/2 carton de poisson séché, 6 paquets de maggi poulet et 60 morceaux de potasse), 3 sacs d’arachide, 5 paniers de poissons frais et 5 cartons de savons.  
Elles s’approvisionnent  en pagnes wax et savons à Bamako, en couvertures en laine et en couvre-lits à Gao, en habits  pour enfants au grand marché de Ségou, en condiments alimentaires au marché Château de Ségou, l’arachide en gousse à la foire hebdomadaire de Boussin, en poisson au marché château. La vente des  habits  pour enfants se fait en ambulant dans les quartiers de Darsalam et de Hamdallaye, les autres marchandises sont vendues au marché château, à l’exception des couvertures en laine et couvre-lits  qui le sont à domicile. 
La vente se fait au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femmes.
