Elles  comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  le remboursement des prêts, à la contribution aux charges familiales, à la participation aux évènements sociaux. 
Leurs ambitions sont : avoir  une maison et pérenniser leurs activités commerciales.
texts.en:
The Djiguiya group comprises six women (two widows and four married women) who are on average 38 years old, with an average of 4 children and living in monogomous families in the Hamdallaye area of the town of Ségou (in the 4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They sell a variety of products, as well as doing some catering, and are on their second group loan, having repaid the first without any difficulty. This loan will be used to buy 5 pieces of "pagne wax" (a West African term for highly decorative and colourful fabric), 3 woollen blankets, 3 bedcovers, 65 items of clothing for children (dresses, trouser suits, skirt suits and baby clothes), food seasonings (150 bowls of powder made from the Baobab - or monkey bread - tree, 50 bowls of chili peppers, 1/2 a carton of dried fish, 6 packets of Maggi chicken stock cubes and 60 pieces of potash) 3 bags of groundnut, 5 baskets of fresh fish and 5 cartons of soaps. They buy their stock of fabric and soaps in Bamako, the woollen blankets and bedocvers in Gao, the children's clothing at the large market at Ségou, the food seasonings and the fish at the Château de Ségou market, and the groundnut pods at the weekly fair at Boussin. They sell the children's clothing while walking around the neighbourhoods of Darsalam and Hamdallaye, and the other goods are sold at the Château market, apart from the woollen blankets and bedcovers which are sold to people in their homes. The goods are sold for either cash or credit to a customer base made up of both men and women. They are expecting to make a monthly profit of 30,000 FCFA which will be used for the repayment of loans, but also to contribute to family expenses and social events. Their ambitions are to have a house and to keep their business going.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various products

loans.name: Helena

texts.en:
Helena is 28 years old and is married with four children aged between 1 and 7 years. She and her family live in Musanze, which is approximately two hours drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Helena has been a proven entrepreneur, selling travel items for the past ten years. She employs three people in her business who work from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day except Sunday.

Helena is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more travel bags and accessories for the purpose of expanding her business. With this expansion, she hopes to meet the growing demand for travel bags and to attract more customers to her shop. If this strategy is successful, she will earn more profit which she will reinvest in her business and be better able to provide for her family and loved ones.

loans.use: To purchase additional travel bags and accessories to sell

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah sells ice fish and foodstuffs. She also has a grinding machine that she uses to grind pepper in the market. With these combined businesses, she hopes to make more profit to enable her to support her husband to meet the basic needs of the home. She has been in this business for a long time.

Sarah lives in Badagry, Lagos state. She is 40 years old and married with 4 children. She hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and ice fish to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more ice fish and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Dorathy

texts.en:
Dorathy sells electrical materials in the market at retail prices. She has been in this business for 3 years. She is a focused, hard worker. She hopes to own an electrical company in the future.

Dorathy lives in Lagos state, Nigeria. She is 40 years old and happily married with 2 children. Dorathy hopes for a loan in the amount of NGN 150,000 to purchase more electrical materials to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more electrical materials to sell

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is 41 years old and married, with ten children aged between 8 and 26. Her children go to school. Fatuma resides in and rents a two room house where she lives with three people. Fatuma takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.

Fatuma sells bananas in Nalukolongo market seven days a week. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She receives an average of 50 customers a day and sells to all categories of people, both retail and wholesale. Fatuma incurs transportation costs going to and from Mbarara, one of the districts in southern Uganda, to buy bananas. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family, school fees for her children and monthly market dues. Fatuma's major business challenges are seasonality and the rainy season which hinders her customers because she works from a muddy place.

Fatuma has been in this business for ten years and with MCDT for six years, servicing her nineteenth loan. She joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. Fatuma wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas. She wants to see her business grow bigger and start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Maemoun

texts.en: Maemoun is a young Palestinian man living in a village near Tulkarem City in the northern West Bank. Maemoun works in a sewing workshop and has a monthly income of $500. Maemoun is 33 years old. He is currently engaged to a young woman, and he plans to get married as soon as his house is furnished. Maemoun requested $2,000 from FATEN to furnish his house. Maemoun appears in the picture at the FATEN office.

loans.use: To purchase home appliances

location.town: Biet Leed, Tulkarem City, West Bank

loans.name: Sakinut

texts.en:
Sakinut lives in Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells foodstuffs and loaves of bread from her stall. She has been in this business for a long time. She sells for long hours to enable her to meet the demands of her customers and the basic needs of her family.

Sakinut is 45 years old and married with 5 children, who are excelling at school and in their trades. Sakinut hopes for a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and loaves of bread to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and loaves of bread to sell

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is married with four children and she is 39 years old. She is a friendly woman and she is also hardworking. She sells tailoring materials in her stall but she is not a tailor. She has been in this business for three years.

Rose is a LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) client and she used a LAPO loan as her capital to start her business. She hopes to expand her business in the future. She hopes for a loan of NGN 160,000 to purchase more tailoring materials to sell.

This is the high season for business and Rose hopes to make more profits. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Meun

texts.en:
Mrs. Meun S. resides with her husband and her two young kids in a small stone house located in the middle of Phnom Penh. Meun S. was not available when the photo taken so her husband is pictured instead.

Meun S. works sewing clothes for the garment industry, while her husband is a journalist for a ministry. This couple typically earns about $7 per day to help manage their family’s living expenses.

Meun S. and her husband face a big problem with transportation to their work location because they don’t own a vehicle. Because of that, Meun S. needs a loan to purchase a motorcycle to use for commuting to work or for going anywhere else.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for commuting

loans.name: Lovis

texts.en:
O. Lovis O. is forty-six years old and is married with three children going to school. He owns a shop business which he has been operating for over six years. His business is now growing into a medium-sized shop still selling general merchandise. This business is strategically located because it is located in the marketplace where the majority pass by.

Lovis is using the loan to purchase retail items such as boxes of pads, toilet paper, boxes of milk, Blue Band (margarine), soap, baking powder, bulbs, and so forth.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for his shop

loans.name: Abiodun

texts.en: Abiodun is 36 years old and married with 2 children . She is a friendly, hard working woman . She sells tailoring materials in her stall and she is a tailor. She has been in this business for 5 years. Abiodun is an LAPO client and she used her LAPO loan as capital to start her business. She hopes to expand her business in the future. She hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. This is the high season for business and Abiodun hopes to make more profit. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Tahani

texts.en: Tahani is a young woman. She is 21 and married with one child, less than one year old. Tahani's husband is working as a police officer in the Palestinian National Authority. His monthly income hardly covers his monthly expenses, especially since his wife is still studying sociology at the university. She is in her third year. Tahani hopes after finishing her university degree to get a job and help her husband on the daily expenses. Tahani requested $2,000 from FATEN to pay her tuition at the university. Tahani appears in the picture at the FATEN office, while signing some papers.

loans.use: To pay university tution

location.town: Aseerah Alshamalya village, Nablus, West Bank

loans.name: Afusat

texts.en: Afusat sells cooked food in her stall in Lagos state, Nigeria. She loves cooking and that was why she commercialized her cooking skills to make money for herself. She cooks Nigerian foods like moi moi (steamed beans cake). amala (yam or plantain paste) and ewedu (a cooked green vegetable made from leaves of ewedu (or jute) plant), rice, beans, and drinks. She is a hard-working woman. She is 31 years old and married with one child. She hopes for a loan of 140,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en: O. T. Mohammed is a male Ugandan who is 50 years old and married with five children in school at the primary level. His wife is also a small-scale businesswoman. He has a retail shop which he has been operating for over four years. He is using the loan to purchase retail items such as OMO (a detergent product), soap, matchboxes, drinks and so forth, for the expansion of the business. His business dream is to upgrade his retail shop.

loans.use: To purchase items such as OMO, soap, match boxes, drinks, etc., to sell

loans.name: Achan

texts.en: Achan J. is a female Ugandan aged forty-three years.  She is a married woman with seven children, some in a tertiary institution and others at secondary and primary level. She began selling small items such as cassava flour before she shifted to operate a drug store. Her store is located in Mvara trading center adjacent to Okuambo market. She is using the loan to purchase various drugs to improve upon her business and to be able to meet her customers' demands. Her future plan is to prosper.

loans.use: To purchase various drugs to improve upon her business and be able to meet her customers' demands.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: A. Margaret is 38 years old and married with four children, all in school. She manages a retail shop business and she has been doing this for over four years. She is using the loan to purchase a variety of retail items, such as eggs, balls, umbrellas, maize flour, sugar, flasks and so on. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to succeed in whatever she does.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of retail items to sell.

loans.name: Fabien

texts.en:
Fabien is 21 years and he is single. He lives in Musanze, a region of Ruhengeri, in the Northern Province of Rwanda.

Fabien has been a proven entrepreneur in the business of selling household items such as saucepans, flasks, jags, stoves, etc. He has run his business for four successful years and employs two people from his community. He starts his work at 6 a.m. and works until 6 p.m. everyday except Saturday.

Fabien is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business by purchasing more household items in order to increase his sales. He hopes to earn more profits and better satisfy the growing demand for these items from his customers. He also plans to save a portion of the revenue earned in order to build a secure foundation for his business.

loans.use: To purchasing additional household items

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 26 years old, is single, and he takes care of two dependents from his family. he lives in the Rulindo district, in the Northern Province of Rwanda that is approximately an hour’s drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Joseph is a self-employed businessman selling different goods (cosmetics goods and some foodstuffs) in his retail shop. He has been in this business for more than three years and he works from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. daily.
 
Joseph is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase additional items like cosmetics goods and some foodstuffs such as sugar, biscuits, cooking oil, etc. With these additional items in his retail shop, Joseph hopes to earn more profits and improve on his savings as well as better providing for his extended family.

loans.use: To buy additional inventory for his store

loans.name: Hilder

texts.en: T. Hilder is 25 years old and married with three children. She runs a supermarket business. She is using the loan to purchase supermarket items such as soap, plates, drinks, sprays, and so on. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to upgrade to a large supermarket where she would sell almost every type of essential goods and appliances for a big profit return.

loans.use: To purchase supermarket items to sell.

loans.name: Joyce Muthoni

texts.en:
Joyce is 47 years old and married to Pharis. They have two sons and one daughter, ages 25, 18 and 13, respectively). Joyce was introduced to Kadet by a credit officer during a marketing activity in Thika-Town (her home town). She has no loan history with other MFI's (micro-finance institutions). 

She has been operating a secondhand clothing sales business for the past twenty years. With this loan, Joyce plans to purchase additional inventory of secondhand clothing (undergarments, men's ties and socks) in order to keep up with customer demand and to maximize her profits. 

Joyce intends to purchase a piece of land and build a home for her family in the future. Her hopes and dreams are to open her own shop and sell new clothes. Joyce is the main breadwinner in her family. Her business is what supports her family, since her husband works on a very casual basis. She remains loyal to Kadet as she has a chronic illness and Kadet has helped in her medication through the Uzima Medical Cover. She describes herself as a hardworking lady and determined to make it in life.

loans.use: To purchase more secondhand clothing to sell

loans.name: Abdul

texts.en: Abdul E. M. is 36 years old and married, with two children. He has a retail business dealing in home products like soap, sugar, plates, and so forth. He is using the loan to purchase more items to sell. Since he supplies goods to shops in Masindi town and its suburbs, he wants to start selling the rare goods that his customers ask for, in trying to meet their needs.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as soap, sugar, plates, and so forth.

loans.name: John Njuguna

texts.en:
John is 33 years old and married to Monica. They have one son who is 8 years old and one daughter who is 3 years old. John was introduced to Kadet by a Kadet credit officer through marketing outreach in Kabati (his home town). He has no loan credit history with other MFI's (micro-finance institutions). John has been operating a motorcycle transport business for the past six years and also does farming as another source of income. John plans to purchase a motorcycle with the loan he has applied for. He intends to buy dairy cattle with the extra profit he generates from his transport business and his sales of farm produce.

His hopes and dreams are to start a taxi business in his home town. John comes from a humble background. He was once a gardener, and he saved from his earnings on a monthly basis. He later managed to purchase a motorcycle which he is currently using to offer transport service in order to earn some income.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for his transport business

loans.name: Susan Wanjiru

texts.en:
Susan is 29 years old and married to James. They have one daughter. Susan was introduced to Kadet through an existing client. She has no loan history with another micro-finance institution.

She has been operating a retail shop for the past six months and also does farming as another source of income. She plans to use her loan to add stock to her retail shop: kerosene, charcoal and other general merchandise. She intends expand her retail shop with the extra profit generated from the business. Her dream is to become a charcoal supplier and own her own kerosene pump. She describes herself as an honest and a faithful lady.

loans.use: To add stock to her retail shop (kerosene, charcoal and other general merchandise items)

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en: K. Godfrey is 48 years old and married with four children. He owns a retail shop and he has been in business for over ten years. He is using the loan to purchase retail items such as maize flour. His dream is to improve upon his business and to become a major supplier of maize flour in his business.

loans.use: To purchase retail items to sell, such as maize flour.

loans.name: Faith Njeri

texts.en:
Faith is a 29 year old single mother, with a daughter aged 4. She was introduced to Kadet through an existing Kadet client. She has no loan history with other MFI's. Faith has been operating a retail shop for the past 5 years and also does dairy farming as her other source of income. Faith plans to utilize the loan to purchase more stock for her shop to satisfy her customers' demand.

Faith's hopes and dreams are to own a farm and dig a bore-hole to be used as a source of extra income by selling water to the local community. She describes herself as a business-minded lady, visionary and hardworking.

loans.use: To add stock (maize, rice, detergent) to her general retail shop

loans.name: Joseph Murigi

texts.en:
Joseph is 39 years old and married to Judy. They have two daughters and one son. Joseph was introduced to Kadet by a Kadet credit officer through marketing outreach. He has been operating a water distribution business for one year and also sells livestock occasionally. With this loan, Joseph plans to purchase two more donkeys, which he intends to lend to other people for water transport. 

He intends to purchase a donkey-cart and employ casual workers to fetch and distribute water to the local people in the community. He also wants to grow his business with the extra profits generated from the business. His hopes are to purchase a piece of land and build his own house.

loans.use: To purchase donkeys for transporting water

loans.name: Edward

texts.en: Edward is 33 years old and married with three children. He started his business six years ago. He is using the loan to purchase retail items: essentials such as sugar, salt, soap, and so forth. He wants to boost his business by stocking all kinds of essential goods; he wants to be a prominent distributor of necessary goods on the market.

loans.use: To purchase essential goods (sugar, salt, soap) for resale

loans.name: Rose Wangui

texts.en:
Rose, 37, is a single mother. She has a son who is 18 years old and a daughter who is 16 years old. She was introduced to Kadet through an existing Kadet client. She has been operating a green grocery business for the past six years. She has no loan history with another MFI. 

With this loan, Rose plans to buy more stock to expand her business and satisfy her customers demand. Rose also sells cabbage wholesale and retail in Muranga town, located in Central Kenya. Rose also intends to start a cereal business (selling maize, beans, etc.) with the extra profits generated from the business. Her dream is to purchase a piece of land. She describes herself as a hardworking lady and respectful to people.

loans.use: To increase inventory in order to expand her business

loans.name: Ephraim

texts.en:
Ephraim is 38 years old and blessed with five children. He is a businessman running a retail business of selling charcoal. He has been in this business for over five years. He is using the loan to purchase bags of charcoal and transport of charcoal to market. 

Ephraim is a hardworking businessman whose dream is to obtain sufficient means of transport so that he can begin taking charcoal and timber to Kampala town for his business expansion.

loans.use: To purchase bags of charcoal and transport of charcoal to market

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah Adhiambo Mauda is a 34-year-old single mother of one toddler: Isaack Baraka, 5 years old. Sarah resides in Kabarnet town, where she operates a business as a fish monger in the Kabarnet municipal market. Sarah started her business nine years ago. This is the third loan she is receiving from KADET.

Sarah plans to use the loan to purchase fish for Kshs 10,000 during the December festive season and use the rest of the money to buy a refrigerator for the storage of fresh fish. KADET Ltd is the only MFI that has financed Sarah’s business. Sarah was introduced to KADET by a business partner who was already a KADET client.

Sarah does her business in Kabarnet town; her clients are residents of Kabarnet town. If her business does well, Sarah plans to expand her business and build residential houses for renting.

Sarah hopes to one day buy a lorry which she will use to transport and distribute fish from Kisumu to Kabarnet and other towns, which will increase her turnover immensely. She also dreams of giving her son a better education than she had. She describes herself as hardworking and determined to achieve her desires and goals.

loans.use: To buy fish and a refrigerator for storing fresh fish

loans.name: Anastacia

texts.en:
Anastacia M., 38, is married to John Nyoro. Together they have ten children. Anastacia runs a fruit shop in the outskirts of Naivasha.

This is Anastacia’s second loan with KADET. With her first loan, she was grateful to have been able to establish her fruit shop. She was introduced to KADET by a friend who is a client.

Anastacia plans to improve her shop by adding stock of fresh fruit so she can sell a greater variety of fruit to her customers. This will enable her serve her clients better, hence making more sales.

Her long term goal is to graduate from a retail to a wholesale fruits supplier.

loans.use: To add stock to her fruit selling business

loans.name: Jane Njeri

texts.en:
Jane is 46 years old and married to George. They have two daughters and two sons, ages 18, 20, 21, and 23 years old, respectively. Jane was introduced to Kadet through an existing Kadet client. She has no loan history with other MFIs. 

Jane has been operating a salon business for the past five years, and she also operates a slaughtering business, which is her other source of income.

Jane plans to puchase cows for slaughtering to sell meat to customers with this loan. She intends to expand her business and supply meat to more clients with butcheries. Her dream is to grow her business to a level of being a meat supplier. She describes herself as an honest and hardworking businesswoman.

loans.use: To purchase cows for slaughtering to sell meat to customers

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is a faithful LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) client. She used LAPO loan as the capital base of her business. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. 

Veronica lives in Agbor, Delta State, Nigeria. She sells crates of drinks at retail prices to her customers. She is 46 years old and married with six children. Her husband is a policeman and he also supports the home. Veronica hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She hopes to own a drink factory in the future. She says thanks to Kiva lenders for your support.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Nana

texts.en:
This is Nana K., a small-scale businesswoman in Makeni city, in the north of Sierra Leone. Nana sells a wide variety of things – shoes, laces, cottons, dishes, sprays, plastic water, drinks, cigarettes, biscuits, soap, etc.  Nana has been doing business for six years now. 

Business had been growing at a very slow pace for Nana until ten months ago when she had her first SMT/Kiva loan. With the help of that loan, Nana experienced a vast improvement in her business and personal life. Having repaid her previous loan successfully, she is again requesting a loan in order to further strengthen her business. She will use SLL 3,000,000 from this loan to invest in clothes and SLL 1,000,000 to invest in other items like biscuits, cigarettes, soap, drinks, and so on.

loans.use: invest in clothes and other items like biscuits, cigarettes, etc.

loans.name: Atimaku

texts.en:
Atimaku V. is currently in the business of selling beans and charcoal and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. She is 26 years old and married to a security guard. She has three children and her children go to school.  ith the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Jane Waithira

texts.en:
Jane Waithera N. is a 51-year-old resident of Uthiru. She is married to Francis N., a 56-year-old hardworking farmer. Together they have six children. Jane’s primary business is farming, which she does with the help of her husband, but she also manages rental houses to subsidize on her income.

Jane joined Kadet Limited through an introduction by a member. She has been borrowing loans and repaying them very well and now she has applied for her fifth loan of 40,000 Kenyan Shillings. She plans to use half of that amount to build a house that she has been putting up while the rest will be used to rear chicks and poultry on her farm.   

She hopes in the future to put up more houses for rent and to improve on the ones she has. She also wants to raise more chicks, for which she can get eggs for sale and also to sell the chicks themselves.

loans.use: Getting into the chicken and poultry rearing business and completing a house she has been putting up

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en:
Jacob O. is 37 years old, married with two children, 1 and 3 years old. His wife sells tubers of yam to support the home. He is an LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa.

Jacob O. sells medicines, groceries and drinks at retail prices to make a living. He lives in Delta state, Nigeria. With these combined businesses, he hopes to meet the basic needs of his family. He hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase medicine, groceries and drinks to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase medicine, groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim K. is a businessman in the northern city of Makeni. He has been selling used clothes for men for over twenty years now. About ten months ago, Ibrahim received his first SMT/Kiva loan which was the sum of SLL 2,000,000. With the help of that loan, Ibrahim has experienced a vast growth in his business and personal life. With the profit he made out of the business, the 38-year-old was better able to look after his 5 children and wife. 

Having completed repaid that loan successfully, he is again requesting a loan of SLL 3,000,000 to further strengthen his business. Born in Port Loko, northern Sierra Leone, Ibrahim finds Makeni a very suitable place to carry on his activity. He will use this loan to buy two bales of second-hand clothes, some bags of rice, and gallons of palm-oil. A bale of used clothes costs SLL 800,000 in Freetown, the capital city. Ibrahim can not specify how many bags of rice and gallons of palm-oil he will buy as prices for such commodities are not fixed.

loans.use: Buy two bales of used clothes, bags of rice, and gallons of palm-oil

loans.name: Achi

texts.en:
Achi R. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol. She is requesting a loan to purchase materials to make more alcohol to sell.

Achi is 46 years old and married; her husband is a driver. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make more alcohol to sell

loans.name: Kiko

texts.en:
Kiko M. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol. She is requesting a loan to stock more materials to use.

Kiko is 35 years old and is married; her husband is a taxi driver. She has 5 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy materials for making alcohol

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Forty-five years old, Fatmata J. sells clothes, dishes, and suitcases in Makeni city. She has been in this business for more than twenty years now. Fatmata is requesting her second SMT/Kiva loan in order to further strengthen her business. Her first SMT/Kiva loan allowed her to make great improvements in her business and personal life. With the profit she made out of it, she was able to look after herself and two children. 

Having completed repaying her previous loan successfully, she is again requesting a loan of SLL 3,000,000. With this loan, she will buy two bales of lace clothes. A bale usually costs her SLL 3,500,000. Thus Fatmata has to add to this loan amount to enable her to buy two bales of lace clothes.

loans.use: Buy two bales of lace cloth

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline sells fried meat, pepper soup, and drinks.The demands for her drinks are high and she hopes to meet the demands for her drinks during this high season. She is a focused, hard worker.

Caroline is 49 years old and married with five (5) children. Her youngest child is 16 years old. She lives in Delta state, Nigeria. Her husband is a farmer. He is into mixed farming of plantains, pineapple, and cassava. He works hard to also support the home.

Caroline hopes for a loan NGN 100,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Jesus Is Real Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'Jesus is Real' Group. They are small-scale entrepreneurs in the northern city of Makeni. They are seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to add more goods to their businesses. In this way, they will be able to make more sales and better profit. Consequently, they can better support their children in terms of feeding and clothing them,  and in their academic pursuits. 

Teresa K. on the left is the leader of this group. She is forty-four years of age, born in the southern city of Bo. She is currently residing in Makeni, together with her husband and children. Her husband is a soldier and two of her children are in college, two in secondary school, and two are already adults. Teresa is a businesswoman who sells fish and meat. She has been a businesswoman for almost ten years now. With her share of the loan, Teresa will buy more cartons of fish and meat to add to her business.

loans.use: Buy cartons of fish and cartons of meat to sell

loans.name: Alayo

texts.en:
Alayo F. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste and beans, and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of groundnuts to make more paste to sell.

Alayo is 21 years old and married; her husband is a baker. She has 2 children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a wholesale shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of groundnuts to make more paste to sell.

loans.name: Ramzieh

texts.en:
Ramzieh is a 44-year-old married woman. She has been working as a hairdresser from home since 1998. She works hard with her husband for better life conditions.

Today, Ramzieh is applying for a loan of $1,000 to buy appliances she needs to satisfy her customers' needs.

loans.use: To buy appliances

loans.name: Peter Macharia

texts.en:
Peter Macharia M. is a 48-year-old gentleman who is married to 44-year-old Ann Wangeci. His wife is a teacher by profession and together they have four children with the eldest being in college while the rest are in primary and secondary levels of schooling. 

Peter has a small candle-making business which he does from his house. He makes the candles and sells them to people in different places where he gets orders. 

Peter joined KADET after being introduced by friends from within a group they had formed to support each other in their businesses. This will be his second loan after successfully repaying the first one. He hopes to use the loan to buy more raw materials for his candle-making business as the demand is quite high now. 

In future he wants to expand his business to cater for more orders as he wants to be able to meet all his family obligations especially paying for the college education for all his children.

loans.use: To buy more materials for his candle-making business.

loans.name: Le We Help Weself Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'Le We Help Weself '(Let Us Help Ourselves) group. They are small-scale entrepreneurs who want a loan of SLL 2,000,000 to enable them to improve their businesses. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs will be accessing from SMT/Kiva. With the help of this loan, they will be able expand their businesses, sales will thus improve, and so also will their sales-to-profit margin. With a larger profit at their disposal, they will be able to better look after themselves and their children.

The leader of this group is Augusta B. S. on the left. Augusta was born in the town of Magburaka, in northern Sierra Leone. She is now age twenty-nine, married to a teacher, and they have one child who is in primary school. Augusta sells shoes, clothes, jeans, lace, etc. She has been doing business for six years now. With her share of the loan, she will add more shoes, jeans, lace clothes, etc. to her business.

loans.use: Buy shoes, clothes, etc. to sell

loans.name: Scholastique

texts.en:
Scholastique is 38 years old, married with three children aged between 8 and 13 years. She lives in Gakenke, a region of Ruhengeli situated in the Northern Province of Rwanda, approximately two hours drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Scholarstique has been in the business of selling local foodstuffs (fruits and vegetables) for two years and employs three people from her community to assist in the daily activities of her business. Her work runs from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day except Sunday.

Scholastique is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing more fruits and vegetables as well as adding drinks to her business. With these funds, she is expecting to gain more profits as well as to satisfy her customers and increase the demand from her community.

Scholastique also plans to renovate her house and better provide for her family and her loved ones.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits and vegetables and drinks to sell

loans.name: Samar

texts.en:
Samar has worked as a home-based tailor since 1999 to cooperate with her husband in raising their child. She's a very hardworking woman and presents a good quality of work to her clients.

Today, Samar is asking for a loan of $1,000 to buy textiles and tailoring appliances.

loans.use: To buy textiles and tailoring appliances.

loans.name: Fatmeh

texts.en: Fatmeh has worked as a home-based hairdresser since 2005 to help her husband in the household. Today, Fatmeh is asking to borrow $US1,000 to purchase cosmetics and appliances needed for her business.

loans.use: To  purchase cosmetics and appliances for her business.

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en:
LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. Rhoda is a faithful LAPO client. She has been a LAPO client for the past six years. She used the loan she got from LAPO to start her business.

Rhoda is 35 years old; she has three (3) children. Her eldest child is 8 years old. Two of her children are in the secondary school, while the youngest child is in the primary school. Her husband is a trader and he also supports the home.

Rhoda hopes for a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more crates of drinks to sell in this festive season. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Mountaha

texts.en:
Mountaha is a 48-year-old married woman with 1 child. She has been working as a hairdresser since 2000. She has been involved in this sector for the past 14 years.

Today, Mountaha is asking for a loan of $1,200 to buy hairdressing appliances needed for her work.

loans.use: To buy hairdressing appliances

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali has owned a special Lebanese tobacco shop in his town since 2007. He's 20 years old and single. He cooperates with his 2 brothers to provide a good life situation for the family.

Today, Ali is requesting to borrow $1,200 to enlarge his business by buying more merchandise and tobacco products.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise and tobacco products

loans.name: Rima

texts.en:
Rima is a 39-year-old divorced woman. She has owned a clothing shop since 2001 in order to earn a good income and cooperate with her father in the household because she is living with her parents after her divorce.

Today, Rima is requesting to borrow $1,200 to buy more clothes before the holiday season to increase her business productivity.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Clare

texts.en:
Clare is married with eight (8) children. Her youngest child is 22 years old. Six of her children are married, while others are studying at the university in Nigeria. Her husband is a technician. Clare is 56 years old and her husband is 57 years old.

Clare's greatest joy in her business is the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes for a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell in this festive period. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Raed

texts.en:
Read works as a taxi driver serving his town and the neighboring villages. He has been working in this sector since 2007 to provide a good income for his family.

Today, Raed is requesting to borrow $1,200 to perform maintenance for his car and finalize some legal registration needed for the car.

loans.use: Maintenance for his car

loans.name: Khaled

texts.en:
Khaled is a 28-year-old single man. He has owned a barber shop since 2004. He helps his parents in the household with his income.

Today, Khaled is requesting to borrow $1,200 to buy additional merchandise in order to satisfy his clients.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise

loans.name: Fadi

texts.en:
Fadi has owned a phone sales shop in his town since 2005, and has 7 years of experience in this field. He's 26 years old.

He plans to enlarge his business, and that's why he is requesting to borrow $1,000 to buy more phones and phone accessories so he can increase his sales and therefore his income.

loans.use: To buy more phones and phone accessories

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine sells colorful sarongs in Agbor, Delta State, Nigeria. She is 49 years old and married with 4 children. Her youngest child is 17 years old. Her husband is a trader.

Catherine is very happy with her business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She hopes for a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is 65 years old and a window with six (6) children. Her youngest child is 20 years old. She is a focused and hard worker. She hopes to excel in her business.

Veronica lives in Agbor, Delta State, Nigeria. She sells cooking oil, tailoring materials and sarongs to make a living. With these combined businesses, she hopes to meet the basic needs of her family. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more cooking oil and sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking oil and sarongs to sell

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
María tiene en su domicilio juegos en red y billar, también se dedica a la venta de cosméticos y tiene un puesto en alquiler donde expone sus productos.

Vive en la Zona de Pazanqueri Provincia murillo de la ciudad de La Paz. 

Su esposo trabaja como maestro albañil en la misma zona.

 Tiene cuatro hijos  los cuales uno ya salio bachiller, trabaja y ayuda a su familia; los otros tres aun están estudiando en el colegio de la misma zona.

El crédito lo destinará a la compra de mercadería (cosméticos) ya que por estas fechas se incrementara las ventas.
 
Es el segundo crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada la califica para otorgarle el préstamo.
texts.en:
Maria has games on the net and billiards in her house. She also sells cosmetics. She has a stand that she rents where she displays her products. She lives in the Pazanqueri area in the Murillo province of the city of La Paz. Her husband works as a master bricklayer in the same area. She has four children. One already has a university degree and helps the family. The other three are still in school in the same area. The loan is to buy merchandise (cosmetics) because sales will increase during this season. It is her second loan with Impro. The completed evaluation qualifies her for the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cosmetics for Christmas sales

loans.name: Isac

texts.es:
Isac trabaja en una empresa como ayudante de mecánica; tiene su esposa y una hija y está estudiando en un instituto privado INFOCAL para  mejorar sus conocimiento y poder mejorar sus ingresos economicos, vive en la zona Huyna Potosí de la ciudad de El Alto.

El crédito lo destinará para compra de una computadora, para poder realizar sus trabajos de la carrera de mecánica que esta estudiando.
 
Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada le califica para otorgarle el préstamo.
texts.en:
Isac works for a company as a mechanic’s assistant. He has a wife and a daughter. He is studying at a private institute, INFOCAL, to improve his knowledge and be able to improve his income. He lives in the Huyna Potosí area of the city of El Alto. The loan is to buy a computer to be able to do jobs for his career as a mechanic that he is studying. This is his first loan with Impro. The completed evaluation qualifies him for the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a computer to prepare the work required for his studies to be a mechanic

loans.name: Feliciano

texts.es:
Feliciano se dedica a la cría de ganado vacuno, cuya producción de leche la comercializa a PIL Andina (Planta Industrializadota de Leche).
 
Vive en la comunidad de Tahari (Achacachi) de la Provincia Omasuyos del departamento de La Paz ubicado a dos  horas y media de la ciudad de La Paz. 

Su esposa solo colabora con los quehaceres de la casa.

 Tiene cinco hijos  los cuales  se encuentran en edad escolar.
 
El crédito lo destinará a la compra de ganado de raza mejorada (una vaca lechera) y así aumentar su producción de leche, por lo tanto sus ingresos.
 
Es el segundo crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada le califica para otorgarle el préstamo.
texts.en:
Feliciano raises cows. He sells their milk production to an Andean PIL (Industrialized Milk Plant). He lives in the Tahari (Achacachi) community in the Omasuyos province, La Paz department. It is two and a half hours from the city of La Paz. His wife only works on the household chores. He has five school aged children. The loan is to buy a better breed of cow (a dairy cow) to increase milk production and increase his income. This is his second loan with Impro. The completed evaluation qualifies him for the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a dairy cow to increase milk production

loans.name: Jackson Kariuki

texts.en:
Jackson is a 40-year-old married man with two children, a son and a daughter. His wife’s name is Rahab and together they have been operating a butchery stall for the past eight years. Jackson is also employed as a driver with a private institution. (We have posted Jackson's wife's photo on the Kiva profile because Jackson was outside his home town when the Kadet credit officer visited the business.)

Jackson and his wife are planning to purchase a motorcycle with the loan he has applied for to reduce the cost of transporting meat from the slaughter house to the butchery, which is expensive because he has to hire public vehicles.

Jackson's hopes and dreams are to own a Nissan vehicle which will be used for offering public transport. He is also intending to educate his children to the highest level possible. 

Jackson describes himself as a determined person and feels he can make it in life.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for transporting meat from his butchery.

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.es:
Ana Maria trabaja en el magisterio rural, tiene dos hijos que están en la edad escolar; el esposo trabaja en el magisterio. Estas actividades son su principal fuente de ingresos con que cubren la manutención de su familia.  Vive en la ciudad de El Alto zona Pedro Domingo Murillo.
 
El crédito lo destinará  a la compra de  material de construcción (ladrillo, cemento, estuco, etc.) para realizar una habitación  para sus hijos.
 
Es el segundo crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada le califica para otorgarle el préstamo.
texts.en:
Ana Maria and her husband both work at the rural school. They have two school-aged children. These activities are their main source of income to cover the maintenance of the family. They live in the Pedro Domingo Murillo zone of the city of El Alto.

This loan will be used for the purchase of construction materials (brick, cement, stucco, etc.) to build a bedroom for their children, so they can be more comfortable.

This is Ana Maria’s second loan with Impro. The evaluation qualifies her to receive this loan.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy brick, cement, stucco, and other materials to build a children's bedroom

loans.name: Hani

texts.en:
Hani is a 48-year-old man who lives in Aley, Mount Lebanon with his wife and their three children. Hani has been spraying all types and forms of aluminum for 11 years.

Hani requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to expand the specialized oven he uses in his work. His clients are stakeholders and relatives; his special work experience and the absence of competitors have been advantages in his business.

In the future, he plans on improving and expanding his business and income through finding a bigger place to work.

loans.use: To expand his oven.

loans.name: Youssef

texts.en:
Youssef is a 25-year-old single man. He has owned a small concrete factory since 2006. He works hard to provide better life conditions for his family, three of whom are unemployed.

Today, Youssef is requesting to borrow $US1,000 to buy tools for his work.

loans.use: To buy tools for his concrete business.

loans.name: Mario

texts.es:
Mario se dedica a la cría de ganado vacuno, cuya producción de leche la comercializa a PIL Andina (Planta Industrializadota de Leche).
 
Vive en la comunidad de Batallas de la Provincia Los Andes del departamento de La Paz ubicado a una hora y media de la ciudad de La Paz. 

Su esposa le colabora con los cuidados del ganado y quehaceres  del hogar. 

Tiene cinco hijos de los cuales una ya salio de colegio y esta  estudiando en la Normal Superior de estudios para profesores; los demás  se encuentran en edad escolar.
 
El crédito lo destinará a la compra de ganado de raza mejorada (una vaca lechera) y así aumentar su producción de leche, por lo tanto sus ingresos.
 
Es el tercer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada le califica para otorgarle el préstamo.
texts.en:
Mario raises cattle and sells their milk to PIL Andina (Milk Industrializing Plant). He lives in the community of Batallas, Los Andes Province, Department of La Paz, an hour and a half from the City of La Paz.

His wife collaborates in caring for the cattle and with household chores. He has 5 children, of whom one has graduated from high school and is studying in the Superior Normal School for teachers. The remainder are still of school age.

The loan will be used for buying a milk cow of improved breed and thereby, augmenting milk production, and consequently, their income. This is his 3rd credit with IMPRO and the evaluation carried out qualifies him to receive the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY A MILK COW TO INCREASE MILK PRODUCTION

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy is married with a child. She is 39 years old.

Joy sells colorful sarongs at retail prices to her customers. She is a focused, hard worker. She puts in long hours to keep her business sustainable. One of her greatest joys in her business is the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers.

Joy is requesting a loan of 150,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Itab

texts.en:
Itab has owned a clothing sales shop in her village since 2000. Over the years, she has become well known by the whole region.

Today, Itab is requesting to borrow $1,000 to buy additional clothes to satisfy the heavy demand of her clients.

loans.use: To buy additional clothes

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 30-year-old married man and the father of 3 young children.

He has been working as a furniture painter since 2003 in his own business, and he has 11 years of experience in this field. Today, Ali is asking for a loan of $1,200 to buy additionA. painting tools and products.

loans.use: To buy additional painting tools and products

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es:
Antonia se dedica a la venta de peluches, los vende ambulando y otras veces en las ferias; es la única fuente de trabajo que ella tiene.

Vive en alquiler; la casa queda ubicada en la  Villa Tunari, Provincia murillo de la ciudad de La Paz. 

Su esposo trabaja como chofer asalariado.

 Tiene dos  hijos  los cuales estudian en la escuela de la misma zona.

El crédito lo destinará a la compra de mercadería (más peluches) ya que por estas fechas de navidad se incrementara las ventas.
 
Es el segundo crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada le califica para otorgarle el préstamo.
texts.en:
Antonia sells stuffed animals. She sells them in various markets and sometimes at fairs. It is the only source of work she has. She rents a home, which is located in Villa Tunari in the Murillo province of the city of La Paz. Her husband works as a salaried driver. She has two sons who are studying at school in the same area. The loan will be used to purchase merchandise (more stuffed animals) because with the upcoming Christmas days, sales will increase. This is her second loan with Impro; an evaluation of her history cleared her for another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Zal Bilimoria, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of more stuffed animals (in high demand during Christmas holidays)

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice sells sarongs in Agbor, Delta State, Nigeria. She is very happy with her business because she has the opportunity to interact with different people. She is also happy because the festive season is here and she hopes to make more profits during this season. She hopes to own a boutique in the future.

Eunice is 32 years old and married with 4 children. Her husband is a carpenter.

She hopes for a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Elena

texts.es:
Elena se dedica a la producción de queques, tortas, empanadas, estos productos los comercializa en las tiendas y también a través de  personas a quienes entrega sus productos en consignación, las cuales  venden en las ferias y mercados.

Vive en alquiler, la casa queda ubicada en la calle Huancane de la Zona de Villa Fátima Provincia murillo de la ciudad de La Paz. 

Es Divorciada, tiene una hija la cual se encuentra en el País de Chile por razones de estudio.

El crédito lo destinará para compra de harina y otros insumos para la elaboración de productos de repostería y así mejorara sus ingresos.
 
Es el segundo crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada la califica para otorgarle el préstamo.
texts.en:
Elena makes pastries, cakes, and empanadas. She sells them in stores and also through people who she gives her products to on consignment. They sell them at fairs and markets. She lives in a rented house on Huancane Street in the Villa Fátima area in the Murillo province of the city of La Paz. She is divorced. She has a daughter who in the country of Chile for her studies. The loan is to buy flour and other supplies to make her pastries and improve her income. This is her second loan with Impro. The completed evaluation qualifies her for the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for making the pastries she sells

loans.name: Khoudia

texts.fr:
-Khoudia  N.
Madame Khoudia N. est une habitante de Yoff  Mbenguene. Elle   est  sociétaire de la caisse de l’U-IMCEC depuis novembre 2003.Elle est mariée  et mère  de cinq enfants dont l’âge  varie entre 12 et 25 ans. Elle  est âgée  de 38 ans et a déjà bénéficié  de 3 prêts  antérieurs  au sein de l’institution. En  plus de ses six enfants elle gère  cinq autres personnes sous sa charge. Elle  a démarré  son activité  de commerce depuis l’âge  de 20 ans. Elle  est spécialisée  dans la vente de tissus, draps et aussi de poissons, activité  qu’elle a apprise par l’intermédiaire  de sa Tante. Son intérêt  dans cette activité  est  qu’elle réalise  des bénéfices  et parvient a s’occuper dans le temps.
Madame Khoudia emprunte  un montant de 150 000 frs dans le but d’augmenter son fond de roulement   et  de mieux valoriser l’acquisition des  produits qu’elle commercialise .Par conséquent   elle pourra  faire face a l’accroissement de la 
demande de sa clientèle.
Toujours dans son optique de participer activement a la lutte contre la pauvreté   l’U-IMCEC avec l’appui positif des prêteurs   réussit   a soutenir  les femmes dans l’exercice d’activités  lucratives génératrices de revenus, ce  qui favorise un développement  socio économique   apprécié.
texts.en:
Mrs. Khoudia N. is a resident of Yoff Mbenguene. She has been a member of U-IMCEC since November 2003. She is married and the mother of 5 children who range from 12 to 25-years-old. She is 38-years-old and has already benefited from 3 previous loans from this institution. In addition to her six children, she is in charge of five other people. She started her commercial business at the age of 20. She specializes in the sale of fabric, sheets and also fish, an activity she learned under her aunt's guidance. Her interest in this activity is to make a profit and hold a job over time. Mrs. Khoudia would like to borrow 150,000 frs with the goal of increasing her working capital and acquiring more of the products which she trades. Consequently, she could meet the growing demands of her customers.

Always looking to actively participate in the fight against poverty, U-IMCEC - with the positive support of lenders - succeeds in supporting women in revenue-generating activities which promote valuable, socioeconomic development.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase of Working Capital

loans.name: Monica

texts.es:
Mónica tiene una pensión donde vende desayuno por la mañana y almuerzos al medio día.
 
Vive en la casa de sus suegros, que esta ubicada en la avenida Coroico de la zona de Zenkata de la provincia murillo de la ciudad de El Alto. 

Tiene una hija la cual esta en etapa escolar. Monica está  separada del esposo.
 
El crédito lo destinará a la compra de harina, arroz y otros insumos por cantidad ya que comprar libra por libara le sale mas caro. De esta forma ella trata de disminuir sus costos.
 
Es el segundo crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada la califica para otorgarle el préstamo.
texts.en:
Monica has a restaurant which sells breakfast in the morning and lunch at midday. She lives in the house of her in-laws, which is located on Coroico Avenue in the Zenkata region of the Murillo province in the city of El Alto. She has a school-age daughter. Monica is separated from her husband. The loan will be used to buy flour, rice and other supplies in high quantity because if you buy pound by pound, it is more expensive. In this way she tries to reduce her costs. This is her second loan with Impro, whose evaluation of her qualifies her for this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Zal Bilimoria, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of flour, rice and other goods for her restaurant

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is married with two (2) children. Her eldest child is 4 years old and her youngest child is 2 years old. Her children are excelling in school. Her husband is a technician. Victoria is 28 years old and her husband is 31 years old.

Victoria is a LAPO client. She hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell in this festive season. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Constantino

texts.es:
Constantino es persona de la tercera edad (mayor a 60 años), por esta condición le negaron un préstamo en otras instituciones financieras.  El, a pesar de su edad, continua trabajando como chofer del transporte publico inter-ciudad La Paz-El Alto, actividad que le genera sus ingresos con que cubre la manutención de su familia; vive en casa alquilada ubicada en  la Zona Villa Tejada Rectangular de la ciudad de El Alto.
 
El préstamo lo destinará la reparación de su herramienta de trabajo (es un auto que trabaja como trufi, es decir con ruta específica) para poder continuar prestando servicio de transporte publico.
 
Es su tercer crédito con Impro, el buen comportamiento de pago le permite solicitar otro préstamo.
texts.en:
Constantino is a senior citizen (over age 60), and because of this, other financial institutions have denied him a loan. In spite of his age, however, he continues to work as a public transportation driver on the La Paz-El Alto inter-city route. This activity generates the income he uses to support his family. He lives in a rented house located in the Villa Tejada Rectangular neighborhood of the city of El Alto. The current loan will be used to repair the vehicle he uses in his business (a car which he uses as a "trufi," that is, a vehicle with a specific route), so that he can continue to provide public transportation services. This is his third loan with Impro; thanks to his excellent payment record, he was qualified to request another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repairing the vehicle he uses to transport passengers between La Paz and El Alto.

loans.name: Christian

texts.en:
Christian is 47 years old and married with a child. His child is 12 years old and in a primary school. He hopes to educate his child to the university level.

Christian is a very hardworking man. He sells engine oil and motor spare parts in Delta State, Nigeria. He is excited to take his first Kiva loan. He hopes to invest in his business with the loan by purchasing more engine oil and motor spear parts. He is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more engine oil and motor spare parts to sell

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela is 54 years old, married, and has two children aged 15 and 27. Her husband is working with an income of 40,000 Rawandan francs /month (approximately $70 US). Angela’s family lives in Burera, in a region of Ruhengeri, in the northern province of Rwanda, which is almost a two-hour drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.  Angela has been in the business of sewing for more than five years, employing three people from her community.  She works at the business from 7 AM to 6 PM every day except Sunday.

Angela has successfully repaid her previous loans in full and on time.  She is requesting her fifth loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to purchase more sewing equipment that will enable her to increase on her clothing sales. With these additional supplies, Angela is expecting to earn more profits that will help her take good care of her family as well put aside some savings. Angela is thankful to Kiva lenders that have contributed to her success in business.

loans.use: Sewing equipment

loans.name: Sylvester

texts.en:
Sylvester has a grocery store where he sells groceries at retail prices. He sells for long hours to enable him support his home.

He is 43 years old and married with four children. His youngest child is 6 years old. Sylvester’s wife is a trader.

Sylvester has been in this business for a long time. He hopes for a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. He says thanks to all who make the loan possible

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal to sell wholesale

loans.name: Angel

texts.es:
Angel, vive en la zona Villa Bolivar  D, de la ciudad de El Alto.
 
Actualmente vive en casa de sus padres.
 
El es un joven emprendedor  pues  hace un tiempo que se dedica a trabajar de manera independiente en su pequeño taller de imprenta donde realiza trabajos de impresión de tarjetas personales, recibos y otros.


El crédito lo destinará a la compra de  materiales, como ser papel, cartulina, tintas, para el desempeño de sus trabajos ya que por esta temporada de fin de año aumentara sus pedidos.
 
Es el sexto  crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada lo califica para otorgar el crédito.
texts.en:
Angel lives in the Villa Bolivar D area in the city of El Alto. Currently he lives in his parent's house. He is an enterprising young man. For a while now he has worked independently in his small print workshop where he prints cards, receipts and other items. He will use the loan to purchase materials such as paper, cardstock and ink to use in his work as in this end of the year season his orders will increase. This is his sixth loan with Impro whose evaluation has qualified him to receive the credit.

Translated from Spanish by Kristina Howe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of paper, cardstock and ink for printing

loans.name: Onyero

texts.en:
Onyero has a big store where she sells clothes and jewelry at retail prices to her customers. Onyero puts more hours in her business attending to her customers; she also has a good customer relationship with her customers. Onyero has two (2) children and her husband is a contractor.

This is the high season for her business and Onyero hopes to make more profits during this season. She hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more clothes and jewelry to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and jewelry to sell

loans.name: Basilio

texts.es:
Basilio  vive, en la calle Huancane de la zona Amor de Dios, de la ciudad de El Alto.

Basilio es soltero, vive junto a su madre en su casita propia en una zona alejada del centro.

Trabaja como empleado administrador en una tienda donde comercializan materiales de construcción, ubicado en la ciudad de El Alto



El crédito lo destinará a la adquisición de materiales de construcción (estuco, pinturas) para realizar algunas mejoras en las habitaciones de su domicilio.
 
 
Es el segundo crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada lo califica para otorgarle el crédito.
texts.en:
Basilio lives on Huancane street in the Amor de Dios neighborhood of the city of El Alto. Basilio is single and lives with his mother in her own little home in a remote zone from downtown. He works in a store where they sell construction materials, located in the city of El Alto. The loan will be used for the purchase of construction materials (plaster, paint, etc.) to make some improvements to the bedrooms of his home. This is his second loan with Impro, whose evaluation qualifies him for this new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Zal Bilimoria, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of stucco and paint for the bedrooms of his home

loans.name: Esther Wakiuru

texts.en:
Esther is 32 years old and married with one daughter. She runs a clothing business. Before venturing into business she used to work as a casual laborer at Delmonte firm.

Esther sells bedcovers, mattresses, curtains, blankets, jackets, and pillow cases.She has been in this business for two years now. Her clients are the local residents. Her business challenges include price fluctuations of goods when buying them. She is using the proceeds of KES20,000 to restock her business. Her goal in life is to become a wholesaler. She describes herself as a hardworking, faithful and dedicated woman, and she dreams of stablizing her family and having the best in life.

loans.use: To buy more bedcovers, bedsheets, mattress covers, curtains and sweaters

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa is 45 years old. She is a widow with five children.

Theresa sells second-hand clothes at retail prices. The demand for her second-hand clothes are high because there are people in her community that cannot afford new clothes.

She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 170,000 to purchase more second hand clothes to sell. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more second-hand clothes to sell

loans.name: Sophia Wahito

texts.en:
For five years, Sophia has owned a business selling polyethylene bags and eggs to residents within a busy residential area of Nairobi. She has one employee in her business.  Her main business challenge is poor road infrastructure during rainy periods. 

She will use proceeds of $675 to restock eggs and polyethylene bags.  Sophia's goal in life is to own a wholesale shop and educate her four-year-old son.  She is married and describes herself as hardworking and humble.

loans.use: To increase stock of polyethylene bags and eggs

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en:
50-year-old Jamila lives in Saida, Southern Lebanon, with her husband and their five children. Since 1993, Jamila has owned a grocery store where she sells candies, canned food, home cleaning products, juices and other products. Jamila has been a microcredit client for six years and has always re-paid her loans on time. When she started her business, she faced few problems except for the lack of diversity in her merchandise. Her previous loans have helped her diversify her merchandise to increase her income. 

She is requesting a loan from A. Majmoua to purchase merchandise and a cash register. Jamila's business is unique because it offers a wide range of products. Her clients are people from her region like family members, friends and neighbors.  She decided to pursue her business to help supplement her husband's income. More importantly, she wanted to have independent work and be self-reliant. In the future, she plans to continue improving her store.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and a cash register for grocery store

loans.name: Paul Maina

texts.en: Paul is 23 years old and single.  For the past year and a half, Paul has been selling home products such as flour, rice, tea leaves, and stationery.  He has one employee at his store. The main business challenge that he faces are fluctuating prices of commodities. He plans to use his loan of $275 to buy ten dozen kilograms flour, five cartoons of cooking oil, and other home products. He aspires to be a wholesaler in future.  Paul describes himself as hardworking, honest and patient.

loans.use: To buy flour, cooking oil, and other home products

loans.name: Oussama

texts.en:
Oussama is 49 years old and lives in Saida, Southern Lebanon, with his wife and their six children. Since 2007, Oussama has owned a grocery store selling candies, canned food, home cleaning products, juice, and other products. Oussama's business is speciA. because he offers a wide range of products to his clients who are his friends and neighbors. When he began his business, he had financiA. challenges purchasing and expanding his merchandise. Oussama decided to pursue his business because he wanted to have independent work. In the future, he plans to keep improving his store. 

He is requesting a loan from A. Majmoua to purchase merchandise for his store. This is the first time that Oussama has requested a loan from A. Majmoua.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his store

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: 40-year-old Christiana is married and has six children. She is a friendly woman who owns a business selling second-hand clothes. For many years, she has purchased clothes from Lagos to sell in Agbor, Delta state. She works long hours to meet the demands of her customers and ensure the basic needs of her home. She is requesting a loan amount of NGN 150,000 to purchase more second-hand clothes. She hopes to own a boutique in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more second-hand clothes

loans.name: Maria Rosario

texts.es:
Nuestra socia MARIA tiene 46 años, es madre soltera y tiene dos hijos. La socia se dedica por la mañanas a la enseñanza. la socia es profesora D. colegio “Valentin Paniagua”. Ella es natural de la ciudad de Cusco. La socia pertenece al banco comunal “RICCHARY CUSCO” de la Asociación Arariwa. 

La socia alterna sus actividades D. hogar con el negocio de venta ropa y zapatos. Ya son varios años con el negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a su familia. La socia requiere el préstamo para hacer mas pedidos de zapatos a las tiendas mayoristas y venderlas en estas fiestas navideñas.         
   
La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Our partner Maria is 46 years old and is a single mother with two children. This partner's profession is teaching in the morning. The member is a teacher at the "Valentín Paniagua" school. She is a native of the city of Cusco. This member belongs to the "RICCHARY CUSCO" communal bank of the Association Arariwa. The member alternates her time between household activities and that of her business of selling clothes and shoes. It has been several years with this business and has done very well thanks to all the effort put into her work. Our partner is hard-working and enterprising, as she wants to support her family moving forward in life. The member requires a loan to make more orders of shoes at wholesale and then sell them in stores this holiday season. The partner is grateful for the opportunity afforded by this loan and likewise willing to abide by repayment schedule for her loan.

Translated from Spanish by Zal Bilimoria, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more shoes for sale during the holiday season

loans.name: Fatmeh

texts.en:
Fatmeh is a 56-year-old widow who lives in Saida in Southern Lebanon with her two children. Fatmeh not only sells clothes but has operated a bakery since 2000 in which she makes “mankoucheh” for which she is especially well known. A mankoucheh looks like a folded pizza. The most common toppings are zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat it anytime of the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning.

Fatmeh is an active woman who is doing her best to increase her family’s income, especially since her husband’s death. Her work is not only motivated by this desire, but more importantly, to sustain her deceased husband’s businesses. She switches daily between each of them; in the morning she works in the bakery, and starting at noon she works in her clothing shop. Her clients are her friends, neighbors and others.

When she first took on these two businesses, she didn’t face a lot of difficulties except for a shortage of cash to purchase and diversify her clothing shop merchandise. She is now requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase commodities for her bakery and some additional merchandise for her clothing shop. Fatmeh has been a microcredit client for five years and has always paid on time. Her previous loans helped her improve both businesses. In the future she plans to keep on expanding her husband’s businesses.

loans.use: To purchase commodities for her bakery and merchandise for her clothing sales.

loans.name: Charles Ojango

texts.en:
Charles Ojango A. is a carpenter who is married and has three children. He operates a woodworking shop in rural Kenya. He has been in business for the last ten years and has two employees. While Charles faces strong competition from similar businesses, he describes himself as hardworking and dedicated.

Charles wishes to use a loan of 20,000 KES to buy wood to make more furniture such as beds and chairs. His goal is to have electrically-powered woodworking machines like routers and sanders. In the future he would like to open two new workshops.

loans.use: Purchase wood to make more tables, beds and wall units.

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en:
Blessing E. is 29 years old, married and has two children, the youngest a year old. She sells used, moderately worn clothing to her customers. She purchases these clothes from Lagos to sell in Agbor, Delta State. She makes 10,000 NGN in profits each month.

Blessing’s used clothes are much in demand by those who cannot afford new clothes during this festive season. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more used clothes to sell. She says thank you to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothing.

loans.name: Justina

texts.es:
Nuestra socia JUSTINA tiene 49 años, es casada y tiene cinco hijos. Ella es natural D. la ciudad D. Cusco. La socia pertenece al banco comunal “RICCHARY CUSCO” D. la Asociación Arariwa. 

La socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con el negocio D. venta leña. Ella distribuye leña a restaurantes, picanterías, pollerias y hornos. Ya son varios años con el negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a su familia. La socia requiere el préstamo para aumentar el capital del negocio D. compra y venta D. leña.         
   
La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Justina is 49, married, and has five children. She is from Cusco. She belongs to the Ricchary Cusco Communal Bank of the Arariwa Association. She alternates her activities between the home and her business of selling firewood. She distributes the wood the restaurants, specialty restaurants, poultry shops, and outdoor ovens. She has had the business for several years. It has been going very well for her thanks to the effort that she puts into her work. She is an enterprising and hard-working mother who gets her family ahead. She needs the loan to increase the capital in her business of buying and selling firewood. She is happy for the opportunity of the loan, and she promises to pay it on time.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase capital in her business of buying and selling firewood

loans.name: John Kungu
